> **Preparation:** Under general anesthesia, patient positioned in prone position with head rest, neutral head alignment, and head fixation applied. Aseptic dressing and draping completed.  
> **Approach:** Midline C-arm used to confirm C3-C4 level. A midline vertical skin incision was performed to cover C2-C5.  
> **Main Procedure:** Using Bovie electrocautery, paraspinal muscles were dissected to expose the C3-C5 spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the bilateral laminae at C3-C5. Subsequently, a diamond burr was used to thin the laminae, followed by punch technique to perform C3-4 laminectomy. The decompression space was assessed, confirming cord pulsation. Significant cord swelling was observed, and decompression was maximized to the lateral margins.  
> **Closure:** After irrigation and bleeding control, persistent oozing was noted, and Floseal (hemostatic sealant) was applied to ensure complete hemostasis. A H-vac line was inserted and positioned ipsilateral to C2 to prevent cord injury. The wound was closed in layers.  
> **Postoperative:** Extubation was performed, and the patient was transferred to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU).

> Description  
1. After general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position with slight neck flexion and head fixation using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative monitoring was set up. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. A midline skin incision was made spanning the C3-C7 spinous process level, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose the C4-6 lamina.  
3. The left C4-6 lamina was drilled and cut using a drill, and the ligamentum flavum was removed with a punch. The dural sac was identified. A trough was created on the right C4-6 lamina.  
4. The posterior arch was elevated and fixed with three titanium plates to complete the open door laminoplasty at C4-6.  
5. Irrigation was performed, and a single Hvac device was inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was carried out.  
6. After extubation, the patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU).

> **Description:**

2. The C-arm was used to confirm the C4 to C6 levels, followed by a midline linear skin incision and muscle dissection. A self-retaining retractor was applied to fully expose the laminae of C4–C6.  
3. Bilateral laminae were drilled. On the right side, the dural sac was identified, and the laminae were completely separated using a punch. The laminae were then pushed from the right to the left side to achieve decompression posterior to the dural sac. A Medtronic Centerpiece plate was placed and secured with screws to perform an open-door laminoplasty.  
4. Baseline intraoperative monitoring (IOM) measurements were taken preoperatively. The motor evoked potential (MEP) amplitude of the right thenar muscle was low, with no other abnormalities noted. This finding remained unchanged throughout the procedure.  
5. After meticulous hemostasis, saline irrigation was performed, followed by insertion of a H-vac suction device. The wound was closed layer by layer.  
6. The patient was transferred to the recovery room postoperatively.

Intraoperative Notes:  
> Description: Left C3-5 Foraminotomy  
1. After administering general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in the prone position. Neck flexion was performed, and the head was secured using a Mayfield fixator. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, and aseptic draping was performed.  
2. Using a C-arm, the C3 and C4 spinous processes were confirmed. A midline vertical skin incision was made. The muscles were dissected with periosteal dissection to expose the left C3 and C4 laminae. Dissection was performed laterally to expose the medial border of the facet joint. The level was reconfirmed using the C-arm. A hemi-lamina retractor was placed to include the left C3-4 lamina and facet joint.  
3. A drill and punch were used to remove the lower portion of the left C3 lamina and the upper portion of the left C4 lamina to perform the foraminotomy. The inferior facet was removed to expose the ligamentum flavum (LF), which showed significant adhesion. The LF was removed using a pituitary forcep and punch. Hemostasis was achieved using Surgicel and Floseal.  
4. The foraminotomy was performed at the left C4-5 level in a similar manner.  
5. Hemostasis was confirmed, and saline irrigation was performed to ensure no bleeding. The wound was closed layer by layer without a drain.  
At the end of the surgery, the IOM showed increased activity in the left deltoid EMG, with baseline readings around 80 increasing to 180.  
The patient was transferred to the recovery room after anesthesia was terminated.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
1. After general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the neutral prone position with head pinning using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was set up. Aseptic draping was performed as usual. No significant findings were noted at baseline.  
2. A midline skin incision was made, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose the C3-4 spinous processes and C3-4 laminae and lateral masses. Facet joint instability was identified, though it was not definitive, and instability was presumed.  
3. Under C-arm guidance, C3-4 lateral mass screws (3.5X14mm) were inserted.  
4. A Kerrison punch and pituitary forceps were used to perform C3-4 laminectomy and laminectomy with partial removal of the yellow ligament. The spinal cord was exposed, and pulsations were normal. The screws were connected to a rod with a lordotic curve to achieve fixation. The laminectomy site was filled with autologous bone chips for facet joint decortication.  
5. Meticulous irrigation with antibiotic mixed saline was performed, followed by insertion of a Hemovac drain. Skin closure was done in layers, and the surgery was concluded. No changes in IOM were noted during the procedure.  
6. After extubation, the patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU).  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Date:** [DATE] 12:03 PM"

A midline vertical skin incision was made, followed by periosteal dissection of the muscles to expose the C3–C7 spinous processes. The upper portion of the C7 lamina was partially removed to ensure adequate decompression. Bilateral C4–C6 laminae were drilled to create a fusion bed, and autologous bone was placed as an onlay graft over the C4–C6 lateral mass fusion bed.  
5. Hemostasis was achieved, and saline irrigation confirmed no active bleeding. A Hemovac drain was placed, and the wound was closed in layers.

Author: Neurosurgery

Procedure: Laminoplasty, Cervical Spine  
Preoperative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis, Cervical Region

Surgery Start Time: [DATE] 2:15:00 PM  
Surgery End Time: [DATE] 5:02:00 PM  
Intraoperative Notes:  
1. After general anesthesia (G/A), the patient was placed in prone position with slight neck flexion and head fixation using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) settings were established. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. A midline skin incision was made at the level of the C2-C7 spinous processes, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose the C3-6 laminae to the boundary with the lateral masses. During this process, C4-5 laminae were noted to be fused, so a trough was created via single drilling.  
3. A trough was created on the left C4-6 laminae and lateral mass boundary using a drill. The left C4-6 laminae and lateral mass boundary were cut with a drill and punch. The ligamentum flavum was removed, and the dural sac was identified. For C7, the upper half lamina was drilled, the ligamentum flavum was removed, and the dural sac was confirmed. The interspinous ligament was also removed using a punch.  
4. The posterior arch was elevated and fixed with three titanium plates to complete the open door laminoplasty at C4-6.  
5. Irrigation was performed, and a single Hvac device was inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was carried out. No IOM changes occurred during surgery.  
6. After extubation, the patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU).  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Creation Time: [DATE] 9:27 AM"

**[DATE]**  
**Author:** [NAME]  
**Department:** Neurosurgery  
**Surgical Procedure:** Laminectomy, posterior fixation  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy, Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament  
**Anesthesia Type:** General  
**Surgery Date:** [DATE]  
**Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgical Start Time:** [DATE] 1:34 PM  
**Surgical End Time:** [DATE] 3:21 PM  
**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
1. After administering general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position with mild neck flexion and secured using a horse-shoe head rest. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was initiated. Aspetic draping was performed.  
2. Alignment was confirmed using a C-arm, and the C5-6 level was identified. A midline vertical skin incision was made, followed by periosteal dissection of the muscles to expose the C5-7 spinous processes. The ossified ligamentum nuchae at the C5-6 level was noted during this process. Muscular dissection was performed to expose the bilateral C5-6 lateral masses.  
3. C-arm-guided insertion of POSEIDON fixation screws (Medtronic) was performed on the bilateral C5-6 lateral masses, which were then connected using a rod. Subsequently, the bilateral C5-6 laminae were drilled to create a fusion bed.  
4. The C5-6 laminae were carefully removed using a punch to decompress the thecal sac up to the level of the ligamentum flavum. Autologous bone was placed as an onlay graft over the fusion bed at the C5-6 lateral mass area.  
5. Hemostasis was achieved, and saline irrigation confirmed the absence of bleeding. A harvesting vacuum (H-vac) was placed, and the wound was closed in layers.  
No significant intraoperative monitoring changes were observed. The patient was transferred to the recovery room after anesthesia was reversed.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Timestamp:** [DATE] 3:20 PM"

Procedure: Laminoplasty, Posterior Fixation  
Preoperative Diagnosis: Cervical Myelopathy  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Cervical Myelopathy, Herniated Disc Disease of Cervical Spine, Nerve Root and Plexus Compression in Intervertebral Disc Disorder  
Anesthesia Type: General

Assistant 1: [NAME]  
Surgery Start Time: DATE 10:14:00 AM  
Surgery End Time: DATE 12:42:00 PM  
Intraoperative Notes:  
> Description:  
1. The patient was placed in prone position under general anesthesia. Skeletal fixation was performed, followed by skin incision, shaving, betadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping.  
2. A midline skin incision was made to cover C4-C6. Dissection was performed along the nuchal ligament. C4-C6 spinous processes and laminae were identified, and subperiosteal dissection was performed to fully expose the lateral masses of C4-C6.  
3. The entry point was positioned 1 mm medial to the central point of the lateral mass, directed cephalad and laterally. A 2 mm cutting burr was used to create the entry point in cortical bone. Screw guidance was utilized to create holes for screw insertion, followed by bilateral C4-6 screw placement. (POSEIDON CERVICAL SCREW 3.5*14 mm, 5 units; 4.0*12 mm, 1 unit, brand-specific screw system "Inothes")  
4. Screws were connected to rods for fixation. (ROD 50 mm, 2 units [45 mm cut])  
5. Using a Roungeur retractor, C4 and C5 spinous processes were removed. A 5 mm cutting burr was used to drill laterally to medially until the inner cortical bone of the lamina was exposed. Remaining bone was removed using a 1 mm or 2 mm punch, including ligamentum flavum. Total laminectomy was performed at C4-5. Due to significant ligamentum flavum thickening at C5 bilaterally contributing to stenosis, partial removal of the facet joint and ligamentum flavum was performed at Lt. C4-5 and Rt. C5-6 to achieve foraminal decompression.  
6. Meticulous bleeding control was applied, with Surgicel and Floseal. Two H-vacs were inserted, and wound closure was performed layer by layer.  
7. The patient was transferred to the recovery room post-surgery. No abnormal findings were noted on intraoperative monitoring (IOM).  
Procedure:  
- Total laminectomy at C4 and C5  
- Foraminotomy at Lt. C4-5 and Rt. C5-6  
- Posterior screw fixation at C4-5-6 (lateral mass screw fixation)  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: DATE 3:36 PM"

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia and underwent fixation with neck flexion. Bethadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping were performed.  
2. After confirming the level with a C-arm, a midline skin incision was made. The trapezius, splenius capitis, and semispinalis muscles were dissected to expose the spinous processes of C4-5-6-7.  
3. From the spinous process tips, periosteal dissection was performed along the laminae, dissecting the multifidus muscles and other soft tissues to expose the laminae of C4-5-6-7. The level was confirmed again with the C-arm.  
4. Drilling and punching were performed to open the left side of the laminae at C4-5-6, creating a gutter on the right side. The laminae were fractured in an open door fashion to laterally shift them, decompressing the spinal canal. For C7, the upper lamina was removed in a dome fashion to achieve decompression.  
5. An enterpiece OD plate (Medtronic, 12mm, 3 pieces) was applied to C4-5-6 and secured with screws. No instability was observed.  
6. Two H-vac devices were inserted, and the wound was closed layer by layer. No significant intraoperative monitoring (IOM) changes were noted. The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.

**Procedure:** Cervical Spine Laminoplasty  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical Myelopathy  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Ossification of the Posterior Longitudinal Ligament  
**Anesthesia Type:** General  
**Surgery Date:** [DATE]  
**Primary Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] 12:45:00 PM  
**Surgery End Time:** [DATE] 3:00:00 PM  
**Intraoperative Findings:**  
- No surgical findings noted.  
- C4 inferior laminectomy performed.  
- C5 laminectomy due to hinge fracture.  
- C6 laminoplasty, right open approach.  
**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. Patient positioned prone with head in neutral flexion, secured with a Mayfield fixator. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline, vertical skin incision was made from C4 to C7 using a Carm instrument. Periosteal dissection was performed to expose the C4 inferior half lamina, C5–6 lamina, and C7 spinous process.  
3. Interspinous ligaments were removed using a rongeur and Kerrison rongeur. Partial removal of the C5–6 spinous process was performed. A C4 inferior half laminectomy was conducted using a drill and Kerrison rongeur, with the dural sac observed to bulge posteriorly.  
4. A gutter was created on the left side sequentially from C5 to C6 using a drill. Subsequently, a laminotomy was performed on the right side using a drill and Kerrison rongeur. On the left gutter side, a hinge fracture occurred during the process of creating a green stick fracture of the C5 lamina using a dissector and punch. To address this, connective tissue and ligamentum flavum between the C5 lamina and dural sac were removed, allowing en bloc removal of the C5 lamina for laminectomy. The C6 lamina was opened on the right side using a dissector and punch to expose the dura. The lamina was fractured and displaced laterally, followed by fixation with a center piece plate and screw, completing an open door laminoplasty.  
5. Meticulous hemostasis was performed, and a single hemovac drain was inserted. The wound was closed in layers. No intraoperative monitoring (IOM) abnormalities were noted, and no other intraoperative findings were observed. The patient was extubated and transferred to the PACU.  
**Instrumentation:**  
- CENTERPIECE PLATE (Medtronic, brand name), 10mm, 1 piece  
- CENTERPIECE SCREW (Medtronic, brand name), 2.6*5mm, 4 pieces  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 3:25:00 PM"

Intraoperative Notable Findings:  
**Description**  
1. Under general anesthesia in the prone position with head fixation using a Mayfield frame, intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. The level was confirmed using a C-arm to ensure coverage of the C3-C7 levels. A midline, vertical skin incision was performed, and the muscular dissection and detachment were carried out to expose both laminae and the spinous process.  
3. Using a rongeur, the C3 spinous process and partial lamina were removed, followed by a punch for laminectomy. The epidural soft tissue was removed with caution, and transient EMG signals were observed during physical stimulation, indicating sensitivity. All EMG signals recovered promptly. The lateral margins of the dura were confirmed, and adequate decompression was achieved on the dorsal side of the C3 cord.  
4. High-speed drilling was performed on both sides of the C4-6 lamina to create a hinge site on the left and an open side on the right. The open side was thinned using a drill and then removed with a punch. The C4-6 right open side was carefully elevated to expose the dura’s dorsal side. A Medtronics center piece plate and screw were used to secure the elevated lamina, performing an open laminoplasty. Intraoperative monitoring showed no changes during laminoplasty. No hinge site fracture was observed. When the C4-6 lamina was elevated and secured, the previously compressed dural sac shifted posteriorly, restoring a normal bulging contour.  
5. The upper lamina of C7 was drilled and removed using a punch. Undercutting was performed to expose the dura’s dorsal side, removing bony structures and soft tissue.  
6. Irrigation was performed repeatedly with antibiotic saline. Hemorrhage control was achieved using Floseal. Two H-Vac drains were inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was performed, and the surgery was concluded.  
No significant intraoperative monitoring changes were noted.  
Postoperative: The patient was transferred to the recovery room.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Creation Time: [DATE] 5:25 PM"

> Tandem laminectomy & laminoplasty (C3,5 LN, C4,6 LP)  
Procedure & Technique:  
Preparation under general anesthesia, patient in prone position with neck flexion, Mayfield head fixator and intraoperative monitoring (IOM) applied. Antiseptics and aseptic draping completed. Approach: C-arm confirmed C2-7 level, midline linear skin incision performed to cover C2-7. Paraspinal muscles dissected to expose C2-7 spinous processes, subperiosteal dissection performed to expose C3-6 laminae and transverse process medial borders. C-arm reconfirmed C3-6 level. Main procedure: Right side drill and punch used to open C3,5; gutter created for C4,6. Ligamentum flavum adherent to dural sac posteriorly was sharply hooked off from dural sac and removed with punch. Left side drill and punch used to open all C3-4-5-6 laminae; C3,5 laminae removed with rongeur. C3,5 laminectomy performed, dura bulging due to ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament (OPLL). Penfield #1 used to open left side, while gutter created on right side for C4,6 laminae. Laminae elevated and fixed with plate and screws for laminoplasty. C6 spinous process removed partially to prevent future pain. Closure: Bleeding controlled with Floseal, 1 H-vac inserted, wound closed layer by layer. Intraoperative course: Left thoracic ep 80% c/w right from surgery onset, no changes noted. Postoperative: Patient extubated and transferred to recovery room.

- **Surgical Findings:** >C3 Lower & C4 Partial Laminectomy + C5-6 Laminoplasty (Right Open) + C7 Upper Partial Laminectomy  
- **Procedure Details:**  
  1. The patient was placed in the prone position with neck flexion and head pinning under general anesthesia. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied, followed by aseptic draping.  
  2. A midline vertical skin incision was made to include the C2-7 spinous levels. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the C3-6 laminae to the boundary between the laminae and lateral masses. The C7 laminae were partially exposed by extending the muscle dissection.  
  3. The interspinous ligament, spinous process, and soft tissues were removed. A drilling procedure was performed on the C3 lower to C4 upper laminae to thin them, followed by careful removal using a punch. The ligamentum flavum was removed, and the bulging thecal sac was noted dorsally.  
  4. A partial laminectomy was performed on the upper C7 laminae using the same method. For the C5-6 laminae, the lateral mass boundary on the left side was drilled to form a hinge, and the ligamentum flavum was removed to inspect the thecal sac. The right lateral mass boundary was drilled and punched, and the posterior arch was elevated and fixed with a plate.  
  5. After irrigation, a single hemivertebra (H/V) insertion was performed, and the wound was closed in layers. No changes were noted during intraoperative monitoring. The patient was extubated and transferred to the PACU.  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]

Intraoperative Notes:  
> Description  
1. The patient was positioned in supine with a headrest and neck elevator to achieve neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by antiseptics and aseptic draping.  
2. Using a C-arm guide, the C3-4 level was confirmed. A paramedian transverse skin incision was made along the skin crease. Subcutaneous dissection exposed the platysma muscle, which was then dissected transversely to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. Dissection between the SCM muscle’s medial border and the infrahyoid muscle revealed the carotid sheath, esophagus, and trachea. These structures were retracted laterally and medially to visualize the C4-5 vertebral bodies (VB) and intervertebral disc. The longus coli muscles were coagulated to create retractor space. CASPER screws were inserted into C3 and C4 VB, with levels confirmed using a C-arm.  
3. A CCR retractor was placed on the longus coli muscles and fixed. CASPER screws were distracted using a distractor to widen the intervertebral space. After a disc incision at C3-4, disectomy was performed using a punch and curette, followed by endplate preparation. Both Luschka’s joints were confirmed. Disc material was thoroughly removed using a punch and pituitary, and the endplate was exposed using a curette. The dural sac was partially exposed medially, with no dural tear.  
4. A cage filled with Osteogrow was inserted into the C3-4 disc space. CASPER screws and the CCR retractor were removed.  
Genesis bone block, Hanmi, 10×10×20 mm, 1 piece  
MC + cage, SpineArt, 14×14×7 mm, 1 piece  
5. After bleeding control, a Jp 1 drainage was inserted into the neck wound, followed by layer-by-layer closure.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]

5. A Centerpiece OD plate (Medtronic, 12mm, 3 pieces) was secured to C3–5 using screws (Medtronic, 2.6 x 5mm, 6 pieces).

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
- **Surgical Technique:**  
  1. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia. A Mayfield fixator was used for stabilization, followed by intraoperative electroencephalographic (EP) monitoring. Bethadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping were performed.  
  2. Using a C-arm and palpation, C3 and C7 were localized. A midline skin incision was made to cover the C3–C7 level. The trapezius, splenius capitis, and semispinalis muscles were split, exposing the C3–C7 spinous processes.  
  3. The left lamina and lateral mass boundary was prepared with a 3mm cutting burr, leaving only the inner bony shell. The area was fully removed using a 3mm diamond burr, confirmed with a Penfield #4 dissector. The upper half of the C7 lamina was removed with a 6mm cutting burr, and the remaining bony shell and ligament were excised to expose the dural sac. The ligament between C6–C7 was also removed.  
  4. On the right side, the inner bony shell was preserved, and the spinous process was pushed to create mobility. The upper half of the C7 lamina was similarly removed. The midline bone was removed to ensure the left and right lamina removal sites met. A 6mm cutting burr was used to remove the spinous process below, and a Kerrison punch was used to eliminate bone obstructing the midline dural sac. Hemorrhage at the C7 lamina cut site margin was controlled with a hemostatic agent (tacocomb).  
  5. The spinous process was shifted from the patient’s left to right to create a greenstick fracture. The ligament between C2–C3 and C6–C7 was severed with a Kerrison punch to allow proper lamina flap expansion. Due to the thickness of the lamina, the right gutter above was burr-cut to create space. The C6 spinous process was bulky, so it was cut 1 cm below the tip, ensuring the lamina extended beyond while the spinous process tip remained near the midline.  
  6. A 12mm centerpiece plate (Medtronic, OD 12mm) was applied to C4–C5–C6, and a 10mm plate (Medtronic, OD 10mm) to C3. Each lateral mass and lamina received a 5mm screw (Medtronic, 5mm*2.6mm) for fixation. Hemorrhage from the epidural vein at the lamina cut site was controlled with bipolar coagulation. The thecal sac was visualized and confirmed to be adequately decompressed. No hinge fracture was observed.

- Text Data: Radiology reports for the MR/XR, the pre-operative admission note, and the operative note.

</CLINICAL_SCENARIO>

<PRIMARY_TASK>
Your task is to analyze the provided patient data and output a structured JSON object that predicts the 1-year post-operative JOA score.
</PRIMARY_TASK>

Analyze all provided data comprehensively:
- Review all imaging findings, clinical data, and patient characteristics
- Identify factors that positively or negatively impact post-operative prognosis
- Synthesize information across all modalities to form an integrated assessment
- Consider which factors are most impactful for recovery
- Provide a precise integer for the post-operative JOA score (0: worst, 17: normal).
- Provide Rationale: Write a clear, specific, and detailed rationale that directly summarizes the most critical factors that led to that specific numerical prediction.
- Consider both the baseline status and expected recovery to determine the final post-operative score.
- The rationale should explain how the imaging findings, clinical data, surgical factors, and patient characteristics contribute to your predicted post-operative JOA score.
</INSTRUCTIONS>

  "rationale": "<clear, specific, and detailed explanation>",
  "score": <integer 0-17>
}

Procedure and Technique: Laminoplasty, C3-6 (Rt side lamina open) & C7 upper laminectomy  
# Preparation: Patient placed in prone position on spine table. A three-point Mayfield fixator was attached to the skull. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed.  
# Approach: After palpation of C2-C7 to confirm levels, a midline skin incision was performed to cover C2-7. Neck muscles were dissected midline to expose C3-7 spinous process tips. Paraspinal muscles were subperiosteally dissected to expose C3-7 lamina.  
# Main Procedure: Soft tissue in the C3-4 interlamina space was removed to identify the ligament flavum and define the C3 gutter boundary. The lamina and lateral mass boundaries were clearly visible from C4-6. A cutting burr was used to create gutters along the Rt side lamina and lateral mass boundaries in sequence from C3 to C6. A punch was used to remove the lamina and ligament flavum. The C7 upper lamina was then burr-shaped, and the thin bony shell and ligament were removed. The same technique was applied to the Lt side, creating gutters in C3-6 lamina for hinge function. The C7 upper lamina was burr-shaped, and the thin bony shell and ligament were removed. The lamina was then retracted to the Lt side to achieve decompression, exposing part of the dura. No dura tear or hinge fracture was observed across all levels. Open door laminoplasty was performed using a centerpiece plate and screw (Medtronic, medical device company).  
# Closure: After insertion of an H-vac 1ea, the wound was sutured in anatomical layers.  
# Postoperative: Patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  
# Instruments: Centerpiece plate OD 12mm 4ea, Centerpiece screw 2.6*5mm 8ea

  - The hinge of the lamina was secured using a 12mm plate.  
- *Closure:* Bleeding control and irrigation were performed. A suction device (H-vac) was inserted. The wound was closed in layers according to anatomical planes.

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
- **Preparation:** Patient was placed in a prone position on the spine table. A three-point Mayfield fixator was attached to the skull. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed.  
- **Approach:** Palpation confirmed the C2-C7 level, followed by a midline skin incision to cover the C2-7 area. Neck muscles were dissected midline to expose the C3-7 spinous process tips. Paraspinal muscles were subperiosteally dissected to expose the C3-7 lamina.  
- **Main Procedure:** A Misonix Bone Scalpel was used to remove the left-side lamina from C3 to C6, starting from the inferior aspect. Penfield #4 was utilized to confirm the epidural space. For C7, a cutting burr was used for drilling, followed by decompression using a punch. On the right side, the same sequence was repeated, creating a gutter with the bone scalpel to enable hinge function. The lamina was then folded toward the right side to achieve decompression. No dura tear or hinge fracture was observed across all levels. A double-bent arch-lamina plate was secured to the lamina, with no significant IOM changes.  
- **Closure:** An H-vac (1 unit) was inserted, and the wound was closed in anatomic layers with sutures.  
- **Postoperative:** Patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  
**Instruments Used:** Capax Plate, GS Medical (10mm/12mm x 2ea/2ea), Capax Screw, GS Medical (2.0*5mm/2.4*5mm x 4ea/4ea).  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 1:40 PM"

Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C7-T1 level was confirmed, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. The fascia was divided, and paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to the lamina and facet joint. The spinous processes of C6, C7, and T1 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear, with a burr used to remove the laminae (total laminectomy for C6-7, partial laminectomy for T1). Additional decompression was performed around the cord using punches. Lateral mass screws were inserted on both sides of C6, left side of C7, and pedicle screws on the right side of C7 and both sides of T1. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. Local bone was prepared for grafting. Cortical bone from the lateral mass was decorticated using a burr, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with Demineralized Bone Matrix (DBM). Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac drains. Layer-by-layer closure was performed, and occlusive dressing was applied to complete the surgery.  
Instrumentation:  
3.5 mm Cervical Screws (U&I): 12 x 1, 14 x 2, 16 x 1  
4.0 mm Cervical Screws (U&I): 20 x 1, 24 x 1

Nut (U&I): 6  
Thrombin: 2 units

Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position with head fixation using a Mayfield frame. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline, vertical skin incision was performed to include the C3-C4 level. Muscle dissection and detachment were carried out to expose both laminae and the spinous process.  
3. A high-speed drill was used to create a C3 lamina hole, and the bony shell was removed using a Kerrison rongeur to perform a C3 laminectomy. Adhesions between the dura and ligamentum flavum (LF) were partially present and carefully removed. Subsequently, a planned C4 laminoplasty was initiated, with the left side designated as the hinge and the right side as the open side using a burr. However, significant adhesions between the C4 lamina and LF/dura were noted, and when the hinge side was opened, cord compression worsened, necessitating an unavoidable C4 laminectomy.  
4. Irrigation was performed, and a single closed drain was inserted. The wound was closed in layers, and the surgery was concluded.  
5. Preoperatively, the patient exhibited reduced thenar MEP in both upper limbs and decreased MEP in the right lower limb. Postoperatively, the upper limb remained unchanged, while the lower limb showed slight improvement. The patient was transferred to the PACU post-surgery.

**Date:** [DATE]

**Patient:** [NAME]  
**Procedure:** Posterior Decompression of the Cervical Spine  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Spinal Stenosis of the Cervical Region  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical Myelopathy  
**Anesthesia Type:** General Anesthesia  
**Surgical Date:** [DATE]  
**Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant 2:** [NAME]  
**Surgical Start Time:** [DATE] 3:06 PM  
**Surgical End Time:** [DATE] 7:01 PM  
**Intraoperative Findings:**  
**Description:**  
**Preoperative Status and Diagnosis:**  
1. **Compressive Myelopathy:** C3/4, C4/5  
2. **Spinal Stenosis:** C3/4, C4/5, C5/6, and C7/T1  
**Anesthesia:** General Anesthesia  
**Name of Operation:**  
1. **Posterior Decompression of the Cervical Spine (C3–C6)**  
2. **Posterior Instrumentation with Fusion Using Bone Graft (Iliac Bone and Local Bone), C3–C6**  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Same as Above  
**Operative Findings:**  
1. **Decompression:** The spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
2. **No Intraoperative Findings:** No dural tear or other abnormalities were observed.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm fluoroscope, the C4–C5 level was identified, and a midline longitudinal skin incision was made above and below this level. The fascia was divided, and the paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints of C3–C6. The spinous processes of C3, C4, C5, and C6 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C3, C4, C5, and C6. Additional decompression of the spinal cord was performed using punch instruments. Eight K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, and C6. A C-arm fluoroscope was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, and screws were then placed accordingly. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. A left iliac bone graft was harvested and prepared. The cortical bone of the lateral masses of C3–C6 was decorticated using a burr, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-Vac drains were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The surgical site was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure.  
**Documented by:** [NAME] M.D.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Document Date:** [DATE] 7:15 AM"

# C4 lamina and C5 upper lamina, C3 lower lamina were thinned using a cutting burr, then further removed with punch and rongeur (laminectomy). C4-5 interspinous ligament and ligamentum flavum showed calcification, fibrous changes, and adhesion. Partial ligamentum flavum specimen sent for frozen biopsy.  
# Upon laminectomy, a lesion previously identified on MRI as an epidural mass was observed. The lesion exhibited a mixture of fat and fibrous tissue. Epidural fat was minimal, with significant adhesion. Pituitary forceps used to dissect the lesion along the fascial plane, exposing the dura. Normal dura confirmed at both C5 (distal) and C3 (proximal).  
# Meticulous hemostasis achieved. Hemovac 1 unit placed. Wound closed in layers. Patient extubated and transferred to recovery room. No intraoperative monitoring (IOM) changes noted.

- **Description:** Preoperative Status and Diagnosis:  
  1. Compressive Myelopathy, C3-4-5, C7-T1  
  2. Previous Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion (ACDF), C6-7  
- **Anesthesia:** General  
- **Procedure:**  
  1. Posterior Decompression via Laminectomy, C3-4-5, C7-T1  
  2. Posterior Instrumentation with Fusion Using Bone Graft (Iliac Bone & Local Bone), C3-4-5-6-T1  
- **Postoperative Diagnosis:** Same as Above  
- **Operative Findings:**  
  1. After Decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was observed.  
  2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear were noted.  
- **Operative Procedure:**  
  The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia. Standard preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the levels of C3-4-5, C7-T1 were identified. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina posterior and facet joints at C3-4-5, C7-T1. The spinous processes at C3, C4, C5, and T1 were removed. With caution for cord compression and dural tear, the lamina at C3, C4, C5, and T1 was removed using a burr. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. Nine K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, and T1 (bilateral). A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites. The lateral mass screws were then inserted based on these findings. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed. The left iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. The cortical bone of the lateral masses at C3-4-5, C7-T1 was decorticated using a burr. The graft was prepared by mixing local bone and iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac drains were inserted. The wound was closed in layers and occlusive dressing was applied to complete the surgery.  

**Surgical Supplies:**  
- Tisseel 4ml x2  
- Thrombin x2  
- Spongostan x2  
- Cancellous Bone Chip 10cc

Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
> #1. Patient placed in prone position under general anesthesia and secured with Mayfield head fixation. Standard skin preparation and draping performed for the cervical spine.  
> #2. C2-3 level confirmed using a C-arm. Midline longitudinal skin incision performed above and below, with fascia divided.  
> #3. Paraspinal muscles detached from spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection performed to expose C2-3 facet joints. Spinous processes of C2 and C3 removed, with care taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear. Burr used to remove laminae of C2 and C3. Additional decompression performed around the spinal cord using punch instruments.  
> #4. Four K-wires inserted into the lateral masses of C2 and C3. Screw insertion sites confirmed with a C-arm. Screws inserted based on this confirmation.  
> #5. Incision made on the left iliac crest for bone harvesting. Cancellous bone maximized and stored separately.  
> #6. Cortical bone of C2-3 lateral masses decorticated using a burr. Local bone and iliac bone mixed and grafted.  
> #7. Rod bent to match cervical lordosis and instrumentation performed. Nuts applied and rod fixed with a driver to complete instrumentation.  
> #8. Irrigation performed, followed by insertion of two H-VAC drains. Sutures applied layer by layer.  
> #9. Occlusive dressing applied. Areas with Mayfield fixation replaced with betadine gauze, then gauze and EB dressing applied.

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. Patient positioned supine with neck extension on the operating table under general anesthesia. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) applied. Standard aseptic draping performed.  
2. Right-side approach initiated. C-arm confirmed C3-C5 level, followed by an oblique skin incision over the C3-C5 vertebral body (VB) cover. Platysma muscle incision and dissection performed to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. Dissection along the medial border of the SCM muscle lateralized the carotid sheath. Esophagus and trachea were medialized. Retractors placed to visualize C3-C5 VB and intervertebral disc. All and bilateral longus coli muscles coagulated. Casper screws inserted into C3, C4, and C5 VBs, confirmed with C-arm imaging.  
3. C3-C4 discectomy performed. Annulotomy followed by curette and punch/pituitary forceps discectomy, end plate preparation. Bilateral uncinate processes confirmed, with disc lateral margin fully removed. Fragmented disc material observed on the ventral side; posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) intact but transversely removed to expose the dural sac.  
4. C4-C5 level treated similarly. Post-discectomy disc space distraction achieved, followed by insertion of a cage filled with DBM (Demineralized Bone Matrix) and allograft bone chips. C-arm confirmed alignment, then cervical plate fixation performed. (Patient has RA and DM, which may significantly hinder bone fusion.)  
5. Saline irrigation performed; no active bleeding noted. JP drain inserted, wound closed layer by layer, and surgery concluded. (Skin closed with steri-strip.)  
6. Extubation completed, patient transferred to PACU. No IOM changes observed pre- and post-surgery.

- C7 cage 12×14×4 1ea  
- Surechip 5cc  
- MedyFuse 3cc (DBM)  
- Cervical plate 50mm 6H 1ea  
- 4.0 variable screw 14mm 6ea

Intraoperative Findings:  
> C3, C4 Total Decompressive Laminectomy  
Procedure and Technique:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone on a chest pad. Neutral head position with slight flexion was maintained, and a Mayfield fixator was applied. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was implemented. Antiseptics and draping were performed.  
2. A midline vertical incision covering C2-C5 was performed after confirming the level with a Carm device. Periosteal dissection exposed the C2 spinous process, lower half lamina, C3/C4 spinous processes and lamina, lateral mass portion, C5 spinous process, and upper lamina portion. The level was rechecked with the Carm device.  
3. Using a Rongeur, the C3 and C4 spinous processes were removed. A drill was used to trim the C3 and C4 lamina into an eggshell-like shape. Subsequently, total laminectomy was performed in the order of C4 > C3 using Kerrison and Friedman Rongeur instruments. The spinal cord was posteriorly bulging, but pulsation showed minimal improvement. No IOM changes were observed.  
4. Bone structures were meticulously organized to ensure full exposure of the spinal cord's lateral margin. Irrigation was performed with massive anti-Bx mixed saline. An HVAC device (1 ea) was inserted into the OP bed, followed by layer-by-layer wound closure. No intraoperative complications or IOM changes were noted. The patient remained intubated and was transferred to the SICU.

**Date:** [DATE]

**Anesthesia Type:** General  
**Surgical Date:** [DATE]  
**Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgical Start Time:** [DATE] 2:35:00 PM  
**Surgical End Time:** [DATE] 5:45:00 PM  
**Surgical Technique and Findings:**  
**Description:** General Endotracheal Anesthesia (GEA) induction followed by placement in prone position on a chest pad. The neck and craniovertebral junction were flexed, and Mayfield skull fixation was applied. The mandible was checked to ensure it did not contact the chest pad. Using a C-arm lateral view, the C3 level was identified, and the skin was marked for incision line. Skin preparation and draping were performed. A midline vertical skin incision was made, followed by fascia incision. The spinous process was palpated, and PVM (posterior vertebral muscle) separation was performed. Using a C-arm lateral view, the level was confirmed to be correct. The C2 lamina lower surface and C6 lamina upper surface were exposed, and a Beckmann retractor was installed. The patient’s left side lamina was cut using a cutting burr and diamond burr. The cutting burr was used to remove outer cortical bone and cancellous bone, while the diamond burr was used to remove inner cortical bone. A Penfield #4 dissector was used to confirm that the lamina was completely separated. On the patient’s right side, the outer cortical bone and cancellous bone were removed, leaving a thin shell of inner cortical bone. The spinous process was shifted from the patient’s left to right to induce a greenstick fracture. The dural sac was visualized beneath the elevated lamina, with satisfactory pulsation. The fracture site was confirmed to not extend inward. A Medtronics laminoplasty plate (10 mm length) was placed between the expanded laminae and secured with 5 mm screws. At C3 and C5, one screw was placed in the lateral mass and one in the lamina; at C4, two screws were placed in the lateral mass and one in the lamina. The laminae were confirmed to be securely fixed. Copious saline irrigation was performed. Minimal epidural bleeding was observed. Hemovac drains were inserted into both PVM gutters. Layered closure was performed in the order of muscle, fascia, subcutaneous layer, and skin. The patient was positioned supine with an MJ collar applied.  
**Immediate Postoperative Condition:** Uncomplicated.  
**Author:** [NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 7:42:00 PM"
}

**Surgical Technique and Procedure**:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone on a chest pad. Aseptic draping and dressing were performed.  
Approach: The spinous processes of C2 and C7 were palpated, and a midline skin incision was made to cover C4–C6. Neck muscles were dissected midline to expose the tips of the C4–C6 spinous processes and laminae.  
Main Procedure:  
- Using a rongeur, the tips of the C4–C6 spinous processes were removed.  
- A burr was used to drill the C4–C6 laminae, followed by removal using a punch.  
- Some epidural fat was excised, revealing a dark red hematoma in the epidural space.  
- The hematoma was carefully removed using a dissector, followed by irrigation.  
- Closure: Hemostasis was achieved, and a H-vac suction device was inserted. The wound was closed in layers.  
- Postoperatively: The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  
Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was not performed during the procedure.

Assistant: [NAME]  
Surgery Record: Orthopedic Surgery (Joint & Spine Center) (DATE)  
Procedure: Posterior decompression, cervical spine  
Preoperative Diagnosis: Cervical myelopathy C4-5-6  
Anesthesia: General  
Name of Operation: #1. Posterior decompression, C4-5-6-7  
#2. Posterior instrumentation, C4-5-6-7, lateral mass screw and rod  
#3. Iliac bone graft  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same as above  
Operative Findings:  
#1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
#2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear were observed.  
Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in the prone position. Standard methods were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the levels of C4-5-6-7 were confirmed. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made above and below, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the facet joints of C4-5-6-7. The spinous processes of C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed. With caution for spinal cord compression and dural tear, the laminae of C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed using a burr. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. Two K-wires were inserted into each lateral mass of C4, C5, C6, and C7. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites. Based on this, lateral mass screws were inserted. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. The right iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. Using a burr, the cortical bone of the lateral masses of C4-5-6-7 was decorticated. The local bone and iliac bone were mixed and used as a graft. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The wound was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing to complete the surgery.  

Thrombin 1ea  
Guardix 3g 1ea

Time of Writing: DATE 17:06"

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
- **Surgical Findings:** Laminoplasty, C5 (Rt. Open) + C4 Lower & C6 Upper Laminectomy  
- **Procedure:**  
  1. General anesthesia was administered with the patient in a prone position and head fixation. The C4-7 level was confirmed using a C-arm. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied, followed by aseptic draping.  
  2. A vertical midline skin incision was made to include the C4-7 level. Paraspinal muscles were dissected subperiosteally to expose the C4-6 laminae. The spinous processes and interspinous ligaments were removed. The C4-7 level was reconfirmed using a C-arm.  
  3. A drill and punch were used to perform a C4 lower laminectomy, with the dural sac identified. The hinge side was formed at the boundary between the C5 left lamina and lateral mass using a drill and punch. A C6 upper laminectomy was performed, and the dural sac was confirmed. The hinge side was opened at the boundary between the C5 right lamina and lateral mass.  
  4. The C5 lamina was lifted, and the ligamentum flavum was removed, resulting in decompression of the dural sac with improved pulsation. Laminoplasty was performed using a miniplate and screw. No hinge-side fracture occurred.  
  5. Meticulous saline irrigation was performed, and bleeding was controlled using Floseal (hemostatic agent). A Hemovac drain was inserted, and the wound was closed layer-by-layer. No changes in IOM were observed. The patient was extubated and transferred to the PACU.  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 9:09 PM"

**Orthopedic Surgery (Spine Center)** ([DATE])  
**Procedure:** Posterior decompression, cervical spine (C3–C5)  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Spinal cord injury, cervical  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy  
**Anesthesia Type:** General  
**Surgery Date:** [DATE]  
**Primary Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] at 10:47 AM  
**Surgery End Time:** [DATE] at 3:35 PM  
**Intraoperative Findings:**  
**Description:**  
**Preoperative Status and Diagnosis:**  
1. Compressive myelopathy, C3–C4–C5  
**Anesthesia:** General  
**Name of Operation:**  
1. Posterior decompression by laminectomy, C3–C4–C5  
2. Posterior instrumentation with fusion using bone graft (iliac bone and local bone), C3–C4–C5  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Same as above  
**Operative Findings:**  
1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear were observed.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C3–C4–C5 level was confirmed. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made above and below the level, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints of C3–C4–C5. The spinous processes of C3, C4, and C5 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C3, C4, and C5. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. Six K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, and C5. The lateral mass screw insertion sites were confirmed using a C-arm. Based on these findings, lateral mass screws were inserted. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. A right iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. The cortical bone of the lateral masses of C3–C4–C5 was decorticated using a burr. The harvested iliac bone and local bone were mixed and used as a graft. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The wound was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing, concluding the procedure.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. A C-arm was utilized to confirm the C6/7 level, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. The fascia was divided, and paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina posteriorly and the facet joint, revealing the C6/7 facet joint. After removing the spinous processes of C6 and C7, total laminectomy of C6 and partial laminectomy of C7 were performed while carefully avoiding cord compression and dural tear. Additional decompression was achieved using punches around the spinal cord. Four K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C6 and C7, and the lateral mass screw insertion sites were confirmed using a C-arm. The rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. A right iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. Cortical bone from the lateral masses of C6/7 was decorticated using a burr, and the local bone was mixed with the iliac bone for grafting. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac lines. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The layers were closed sequentially, and the surgical site was dressed with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure.

Procedure: Posterior Decompression of the Cervical Spine (C3-4-5-6), Total Laminectomy for Decompression, Posterior Instrumentation with Lateral Mass Screws, Posterolateral Fusion Using Bone Graft (Iliac Bone, Local Bone, and [BRAND]), Cervical Spine

Operative Findings:  
1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released, and root-free status was confirmed.  
2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear were observed.  
Operative Procedure:  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position on the spinal table under general anesthesia. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. The C3-4-5-6 level was confirmed using a C-arm. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made above and below the level, and the fascia was divided.  
2. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the facet joints of C3-4-5-6.  
3. The spinous process at the target level was removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear, and a burr was used to perform laminectomy at C3-4-5-6.  
4. Additional decompression around the spinal cord was performed using punches. Eight K-wires were inserted into the laminae of C3-4-5-6. The screw insertion sites were confirmed using a C-arm, and vertex screws were inserted.  
5. The right iliac bone was harvested from the PSIS area to prepare the bone graft.  
6. A CG DBM (5cc) was used to perform bone grafting at C3-4-5-6.  
7. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines and one JP drain were placed at the iliac bone harvest site.  
8. The wound was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing. Philadelphia straps were applied, and the surgery was concluded.  
Thrombin (2 units), [BRAND] (6g, 1 unit)

Intraoperative Notable Events:  
Method and Findings > Description  
1. After general anesthesia, the patient was placed in a prone position on a horseshoe headrest. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was set up. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. The C5-6 spinous process level was confirmed using a C-arm fluoroscope. A midline skin incision was made spanning the C5-6 spinous processes, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose the C5-6 lamina.  
3. The C5-6 lamina and spinous processes were removed using a punch. The ligamentum flavum was excised, and the dural sac was identified.  
4. Irrigation was performed, and a single Hemovac suction device was inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was carried out. No changes in IOM were noted during the procedure.  
5. After extubation, the patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU).  
Documented by: [NAME]

**Name of Operation:**

**Operative Findings:**  
#1. After Decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C3–C4–C5–C6–C7 levels were identified. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made below C4–C5, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints of C3–C4–C5–C6–C7. The spinous processes of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. Ten K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which guided the placement of the screws. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. Subsequently, the left iliac crest bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. Using a burr, the cortical bone of the lateral masses of C3–C4–C5–C6–C7 was decorticated, and the local bone graft was placed. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. The wound was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure.

Name of Operation: #1. Posterior decompression and instrumentation with fusion using bone graft (iliac, local bone and BonGros), C4-5-6-7; #2. Posterior decompression and instrumentation with fusion using bone graft (iliac bone & local bone), T2-3

The cortical bone of the lateral masses of C4-5-6-7 was decorticated using a burr. Local bone and iliac bone were mixed and used as graft material. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac drains were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. Anesthesia Type: General  
Surgery Date: DATE

Assistant: [NAME]  
Surgical Record: Neurosurgery (DATE)  
Procedure: C2-6 laminectomy and lateral mass screw fixation  
Preoperative Diagnosis: Cervical myelopathy  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Spinal cord injury, cervical  

Anesthesia Type: General  
Surgery Date: DATE  
Surgeon 1: [NAME]  
Assistant 1: [NAME]  
Surgery Start Time: DATE 8:34:00 PM  
Surgery End Time: DATE 10:45:00 PM  
Intraoperative Notable Findings:  
* Initial check revealed weak bilateral thenar motor evoked potential (MEP) amplitude. During surgery, right thenar MEP remained similar, while left thenar amplitude slightly increased. No significant intraoperative monitoring (IOM) changes were noted until surgery completion.  
* Instability of the C4-6 vertebral body (VB) was evident during screw insertion. This is likely responsible for repeated trauma leading to syrinx formation.  
* Lateral mass screw details:  
- C4 Right: 3.5mm diameter, 12mm length  
- C4 Left, C5 Both, C6 Both: 3.5mm diameter, 14mm length  

Surgical Technique and Findings:  
1. Patient positioned prone in neutral alignment with head pinning using the Mayfield head fixator. Standard aseptic draping was performed. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was initiated. Initial check revealed weak bilateral thenar MEP amplitude.  
2. C-arm confirmed levels, followed by midline linear skin incision from C2 spinous process to C7 spinous process. Paraspinal muscles were dissected subperiosteally and retracted using a cerebellar retractor to expose laminae.  
3. Lateral mass screws were inserted bilaterally at C4, C5, and C6. Instability of the C4-6 VB was noted during screw insertion, likely causing repeated trauma and syrinx formation. Screws were inserted with entry at the midpoint of each lateral mass, using a sagittal angle of 20' and axial angle of 20' in a bicortical fashion. Screws were connected to a rod.  
4. C2-C6 spinous processes were removed using a rongeur and punch, collected for future fusion. The exposed lateral mass and posterior column were drilled and decorticated.  
5. Laminae and remaining posterior arch from C7 level were removed using a punch and rongeur, exposing ligamentum flavum and epidural fat. These were removed to expose the dural sac, which showed minimal pulsation and a severely narrowed canal. C2-C6 laminectomy was completed with a punch, confirming no bleeding.  
6. Autologous bone collected for posterior fusion was decorticated and placed over the decorticated lateral masses. Right thenar MEP remained stable, while left thenar amplitude slightly increased. No significant IOM changes were observed.  
7. A 1ea Hvac insertion was performed, followed by layer-by-layer closure of muscle, subcutaneous tissue, and skin. Surgery concluded.  
8. Patient transferred to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU).  
Recorded by: [NAME] [NAME]  
Date and Time: DATE 10:31 PM"
}

Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C5-6 level was confirmed, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. Fascia was divided, and paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the C5-6 facet joint. After removing the spinous process, decompression was performed with caution for cord compression and dural tear using a burr to remove the lamina of C5-6. Additional decompression was performed around the cord using punches. K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C5 and C6, and the lateral mass screw insertion sites were confirmed using a C-arm. Lateral mass screws were then inserted based on this confirmation. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. Right iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. Cortical bone of the lateral masses of C5-6 was decorticated using a burr, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-Vac lines. A single JP drain was inserted at the iliac bone harvest site. Layer-by-layer closure was performed, followed by occlusive dressing to complete the surgery.  

Thrombin 1 unit  
Spongostan 2 units  
Oxiplex 1 mL

Intraoperative Notes:  
**Description**  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position with neutral neck alignment and head fixation using a Mayfield carbon fixator. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic dressing and draping were performed.  
2. A midline skin incision was made to expose the cervical spine from C2 to C7 using a C-arm fluoroscope. Paraspinal muscle dissection was performed. The muscle adherent to the lamina was detached using a Penfield #1 retractor. The interlaminar space was dissected with a monopolar coagulator to fully expose the C2 to C7 levels.  
3. After level confirmation via C-arm fluoroscopy, pedicle screws (20mm poly) were initially inserted at the left C4,5,6 levels. A 2mm burr was used to create the screw trajectory, and the internal anatomy (e.g., arteries) was confirmed using a ball tip before insertion. Subsequently, pedicle screws were attempted on the right C4-5-6 levels. During insertion of the C5 pedicle screw, misalignment was detected via C-arm fluoroscopy. Reorienting the screw would risk pedicle fracture, so the right C5 pedicle screw was omitted.  
4. A rod was bent and inserted, followed by application of a cap. The final cap was tightened.  
5. A rongeur was used to remove the C3-4 spinous processes. A Kerrison punch and burr were employed to perform laminectomy at C3-4, exposing the spinal cord. The cortex around C3-C6 was partially removed using a burr, and autologous bone was placed on top.  
6. Massive saline irrigation and hemostasis were performed. Two H-vac devices were inserted, and the wound was closed in layers.  
Intraoperative IOM showed no changes. The patient was transferred to the ICU postoperatively.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Timestamp: DATE 8:55 PM"

**Intraoperative Findings & Procedures:**  
1. General anesthesia was administered, with the patient positioned in the prone position. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) system was applied, and aseptic draping was completed.  
2. A midline vertical skin incision was performed to expose the C3-C5 lamina. Paravertebral muscles were dissected to expose the C3-C5 lamina. The spinous process of C4 was removed, and the lamina was drilled and thinned. A sliding punch was used to perform the C4 laminectomy.  
3. The lower half of the C3 lamina and the upper half of the C5 lamina were additionally removed. Hemostasis was achieved using novacol (a hemostatic agent), followed by saline irrigation. A single H-vac line was applied, and layer-by-layer closure was performed.

**Date of Surgery (MM/DD/YY):** [DATE]  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy, C4-5-6-7  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy, C4-5-6-7  
**Name of Operation:** Posterolateral fusion, C4-5-6-7  
**Operative Findings:**  
1. Severe spinal canal stenosis was observed at levels 4-5, 6-7, with particularly significant cord compression at the C4-5 level.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed. Using a C-arm, the C5 level was marked, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision and fascia division. Paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose all facet joints, after which the spinous process was removed using a bone cutter. Under microscopic visualization, burrs, Roungers, and punches were used to remove the spinous processes and posterior longitudinal ligament (PLC) at C4-7, with eight lateral mass screws inserted.  
A separate incision was made on the right iliac crest for bone harvesting. Cancellous bone was maximized and stored separately. A rod was used to compress C4-7, and instrumentation was performed. The harvested iliac bone and local decompressed bone graft were placed along the rod’s sides to achieve lateral fusion.  
After copious irrigation, the paraspinal muscles were debrided. Two H-vac lines were inserted for layer-by-layer closure. Occlusive dressing was applied, and the procedure was concluded.  
**Implants:**  
PRIMA OCT spinal screws: 3.5x12 (3), 14 (4) / 4.0x10 (1) (total 8 screws)  
Rod: 50mm (2 rods)  
Nuts: 8  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Date of Documentation:** [DATE] [TIME]"

Intraoperative Findings: After decompression, the spinal cord exhibited posterior bulging.  
Procedure Description:  
1. Patient positioned prone with neck in neutral alignment and head stabilized using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was initiated. Aseptic draping performed as usual.  
2. Midline skin incision made at the C2-C6 spinous process level. Subperiosteal dissection extended to expose C3-5 laminae, with lateral mass boundaries identified. C3-4 interspinous ligament and C3 spinous process removed using a roungeur.  
3. Trough created on the left side of C3 lamina using a drill. Laminae gradually removed with a punch, repeated on the right side. Ligamentum flavum and soft tissues below the laminae excised to visualize the dural sac. Post-decompression dural bulging confirmed; 5mg dexa administered intravenously.  
4. For C4 laminae, trough created on the left lateral mass boundary. Right-side lamina and ligamentum flavum removed with a punch. Spinous processes shifted to the left to accommodate the dural sac. Centerpiece plate trimmed to fit the spinous process tip. Medtronic OD plate 10mm installed over C4 laminae and spinous process, secured with screws.  
5. Hemostasis achieved with flosseal. Anti-mixed saline irrigation performed. Hemovac 1 unit inserted. Wound closed in layers.  
6. Patient returned to supine position with brace applied, extubated, and transferred to PACU. No intraoperative monitoring changes noted.  
Equipment Used: Medtronic OD plate 10mm (1 unit), Medtronic screws 2.6*5mm (4 units)  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]

Intraoperative Notes:  
> C3-C6 laminoplasty, C7 upper laminectomy  
Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. Patient placed in prone position under general anesthesia. Mayfield fixator applied for fixation, intraoperative electrophysiological monitoring implemented, followed by betadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping.  
2. C-arm and palpation confirmed C2 and C7 landmarks. Midline skin incision performed to cover C2-C7 level. Trapezius, splenius capitis, and semispinalis muscles split, exposing C3-C7 spinous process tips.  
3. Left-side lamina and lateral mass boundary delineated using a 3 mm cutting burr to leave an inner bony shell. The area fully excised with a 3 mm diamond burr, confirmed with Penfield #4 dissector. C7 lamina upper half removed with a 6 mm cutting burr, with remaining bony shell and ligament removed to expose the dural sac. C6-C7 ligament excised.  
4. Right-side inner bony shell preserved, spinous process displaced to create mobility. C7 lamina upper half removed using the same technique as the left side. Midline bone removed to ensure the C7 lamina cut sites meet. 6 mm cutting burr used to remove spinous process below, with Kerrison punch to eliminate structures compressing the dural sac. Bleeding at C7 lamina cut margin controlled with surgicel.  
5. Spinous process displaced from left to right to create a greenstick fracture. C2-C3 and C6-C7 ligaments severed with Kerrison punch to allow lamina flap expansion. Lamina thickness required 3 mm cutting burr to create space. C6 spinous process bulk reduced by cutting 1 cm below the tip, leaving lamina intact and spinous process tip near midline. C5 spinous process tip similarly trimmed.  
6. 12 mm centerpiece plate inserted at C3, C4, C5, and C6. Lateral masses and laminae secured with 5 mm screws. Epidural vein bleeding at lamina cut site managed with bipolar coagulation. Thecal sac confirmed with adequate decompression. No hinge fracture observed.  
*Instrumentation: 12 mm centerpiece plate [ORG] OD, 4 pieces; 5 mm centerpiece screw [ORG] 2.6 mm, 8 pieces*  
Postoperative: Hemovac 2 pieces inserted, wound closed in layers. No significant intraoperative IOM changes. Patient repositioned to supine for dorsal split (DS) operation on nasal fracture, head fixator removed.  

Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: [DATE] 18:35"

Meticulous hemostasis and copious saline irrigation were performed. A Jackson-Pratt drain was placed, and the wound was closed in layers before concluding the procedure.

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the supine position with intraoperative monitoring (IOM) applied. Baseline motor evoked potentials (MEP) and somatosensory evoked potentials (SEP) were confirmed. The patient was then repositioned to the prone position with skull fixation. After slight neck flexion, no changes in MEP or SEP were observed, confirming stability. A partial posterior hairline shave was performed, followed by C-arm guidance to identify the C3-C6 level. A midline vertical skin incision was marked, and the area was prepared with betadine, painted, and draped aseptically.  
2. After skin incision, subcutaneous dissection was performed along the midline. The C2-C7 spinous processes were identified, and paraspinal muscles were dissected subperiosteally to expose the C3-C6 laminae and lateral masses.  
3. Under C-arm guidance, lateral mass screws were inserted into the right C4, C5, C6 and left C3, C4, C5, C6 (Vertex screws, Medtronics, M 3.5*14 - 6 pieces, M 4.0*14 - 1 piece (right C6)). The right C3 lateral mass screw insertion failed twice due to lateral displacement, with correction attempted but ultimately abandoned due to risk of vertebral artery or spinal cord injury.  
4. Under microscopic visualization, laminectomy was performed at C4-5, and partial laminectomy was conducted on the lower half of C3 and upper half of C6. After removal of the ligamentum flavum, the exposed spinal cord showed significant swelling but maintained good pulsation. Decompression of neural structures was confirmed, and meticulous hemostasis was achieved using agents such as Floseal. Autologous bone harvested during laminectomy was applied to the screw and rod insertion sites to promote bone fusion.  
5. A single H-vac line was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers.  
**Intraoperative Monitoring:** No changes observed; post-surgery, the patient regained consciousness and was transferred to the recovery room.

**Date:** [DATE]  
**Author:** [NAME]  
**Department:** Orthopedic Surgery (Joint and Spine Center)  
**Patient:** [NAME]  
**Procedure:** Posterior Decompression, Cervical Spine  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical Myelopathy  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical Myelopathy  
**Anesthesia Type:** General  
**Surgery Date:** [DATE]  
**Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgical Findings:**  
1. **Decompression:** Posterior decompression was performed, revealing cord release and dural pulsation.  
2. **Intraoperative Observations:** No dural tear or other abnormalities were noted.  
**Surgical Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C3-C7 level was confirmed, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. Fascia was divided, and paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the C3-C7 facet joints. Spinous processes of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear, with a burr used to remove the laminae of C3-C7. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punch instruments. Ten K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3-C7, and their positions were confirmed using a C-arm. Lateral mass screws were then inserted accordingly. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. The right iliac bone was harvested for bone graft preparation. Cortical bone of the lateral masses of C3-C7 was decorticated using a burr, and grafting was performed with a mixture of local bone and iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines were inserted, and one JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. Layer-by-layer closure was performed, followed by occlusive dressing to complete the surgery.  

**Author:** [NAME]  
**Time:** [DATE] [TIME]"
}

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
- **Surgical Findings:** C3-4 laminectomy, C5-6 laminoplasty (left side lamina open)  
- **Procedure and Technique:**  
  1. **Preparation:** Patient placed in prone position. A three-point Mayfield fixator was attached to the skull. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed.  
  2. **Approach:** Palpation of C2-C7 confirmed the level. A midline skin incision was made to cover the C2-7 area. Neck muscles were dissected midline to expose the C3-6 spinous process tips. Subperiosteal dissection of paraspinal muscles was performed to expose the C3-6 lamina.  
  3. **Main Procedure:** A cutting burr was used to remove the C3 lamina, followed by laminectomy. The ligamentum flavum was removed to achieve adequate decompression. For C4-6, the right side lamina was removed using a cutting burr, with some sections removed using a punch to create a gutter. The left side lamina was similarly processed using a cutting burr and punch to remove the lamina. Due to concern for kinking from the lamina at C4, laminectomy was performed. Decompression was achieved by retracting the lamina at C5-6. No dura tear or hinge fracture was noted across all levels. A double-bent arch-lamina plate was secured to the lamina.  
  4. **Closure:** After insertion of an H-vac 1ea, the wound was sutured in anatomic layers.  
  5. **Postoperative:** The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  
**Instruments Used:**  
- Gesmedical Capax OD Plate 10mm  
- Medtronic Centerpiece OD Plate 10mm  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Timestamp:** [DATE] at 12:10 PM"
