1. Patient placed in supine position under general anesthesia. Skeletal fixation performed, followed by skin preparation, betadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) applied. Initial bilateral deltoid and left thenar motor evoked potentials (MEPs) showed a reduction to approximately 80-100 µV.  
2. C-arm confirmed for midline skin incision to cover C3-C6. Dissection followed the nuchal ligament. C3-C6 spinous processes and laminae were identified, and subperiosteal dissection was performed to fully expose the lateral masses of C3-C6.  
3. Entry points were placed 1 mm medial to the central point of the lateral masses, directed cephalad and laterally. A 2 mm cutting burr was used to create cortical entry points. Under C-arm guidance, screw guidance was utilized to create holes for screw insertion, followed by screw placement. Bilateral C3-C6 lateral mass screws inserted. (POSEIDON Cervical Screw System, 3.5*14 mm, 8 pieces, InoTh)  
4. A bent rod was connected to both sides of the screws for fixation. (Rod, 60 mm, 2 pieces)  
5. Using a Roungeur retractor, C3-5 spinous processes were removed. A 5 mm cutting burr was used to drill laterally to medially until the inner cortical bone of the laminae was exposed. Remaining bone was removed using a 1 mm or 2 mm punch, achieving total laminectomy at C3-5. C3 showed relatively less stenosis, while C5 exhibited more severe stenosis. C6 showed minimal stenosis, so partial decompression was performed on the upper portion using drilling and punching.  
6. Meticulous bleeding control was performed, followed by application of Floseal. Two H-vac devices were inserted, and wound closure was performed layer by layer.  
7. Intraoperative monitoring showed bilateral deltoid and left thenar MEPs increased to over 200 µV and remained elevated until surgery completion.  
Postoperative: Patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: DATE, 5:11 PM"
}

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
> Name of Procedure: Posterior Lumbar Fixation (PLF), C3-4-5-6-7  
> Operative Finding: Using a burr, laminectomy was performed at C3-4-5-6-7 levels, followed by central decompression. Sufficient decompression was confirmed. Both C3-4-5-6-7 facet joints were fused. No dural tear occurred during the procedure.  

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Routine preparation and draping were performed on the cervical spine. Using a C-arm fluoroscope, the C3-4-5-6-7 levels were identified. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made above and below the target area, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints at C3-4-5-6-7. The spinous processes at C3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 were removed. With caution for cord compression and dural tear, the laminae at C3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 were removed using a burr. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punch instruments. K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, 4, 5, 6, and 7. The C-arm fluoroscope was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which were then used as a reference for screw placement. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. Both C3-4-5-6-7 facet joints were fused. Autogenous bone and demineralized bone matrix (DBM) at 5 mL were inserted into the fusion site. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-Vac drains were inserted. The surgical site was closed in layers and secured with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure.  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Date and Time of Writing:** [DATE] at 4:00 PM"

Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C4, C5, and C6. Additional decompression was performed around the cord using punch techniques. Six K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C4, C5, and C6. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which were then referenced for screw placement. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed. The right iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. Using a burr, the cortical bone of the lateral masses at C5-6 was decorticated, and the local bone was mixed with the iliac bone graft. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The layers were closed sequentially, and an occlusive dressing was applied to complete the procedure.  

**Implants**:  
Vertex Screw 3.5 x 10mm (4ea), 3.5 x 12mm (2ea)  
Thrombin 1ea  
Guardix 3g 1ea  

**Author**: [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Date**: [DATE]"
}

**Surgical Technique and Findings:**  
1. General anesthesia was administered, with evoked potential (EP) monitoring performed (4 extremities). The patient was positioned prone with head fixation using a MJ collar.  
2. Antiseptic dressing and draping were applied.  
3. A linear skin incision was made along the midline, extending from 4 cm below the inion to the C7 spinous process, measuring 12 cm in length.  
4. Midline dissection of the muscles was performed. Minimal bleeding was observed. Dissection was carried out laterally from the lateral margins of the spinous processes, using a osteotome for lateral retraction and Bovie electrocautery for coagulation and dissection.  
5. After confirming the anatomical levels, a 3 mm cut was made using a diamond burr. The right C4,5,6 laminae were removed medially, leaving only the inner cortical bone, while a laminotomy was performed on the left at the same level. The spinous process was shifted laterally to create space via a greenstick fracture of the laminae.  
6. Post-laminoplasty, the expanded space was confirmed. A double laminoplasty plate (Medtronics) was used to fix the C4,5,6 laminae in a spread position. (Plate dimensions: 12 mm/12 mm/12 mm; screws: 7 mm × 3, 5 mm × 2, 7 mm × 1, 7 mm × 2, 5 mm × 1). The laminae were secured firmly.  
7. After meticulous hemostasis, hemovac catheters were inserted into the bilateral posterior vertebral musculature (PVM) gutters.  
8. The wound was closed in layers.  
9. The patient was transferred to the postoperative care unit without significant complications.  

**Monitoring:**  
During anesthesia induction, evoked potential (EP) changes were monitored. The patient was repositioned to supine without any EP changes. Baseline latency for SEP was slightly prolonged compared to normal, but no further increase or amplitude reduction was observed. MEP responses were absent from the beginning and remained absent until the end of the procedure.

Intraoperative Notes:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned supine with intraoperative monitoring (IOM) applied. Baseline motor evoked potentials (MEP) and somatosensory evoked potentials (SEP) were confirmed. The neck collar was applied, and the patient was repositioned to prone. After skull fixation and achieving neutral position, MEP and SEP remained stable, confirming no change. The neck collar was removed. Partial shaving of the posterior neck area was performed, followed by C-arm guidance for level verification. Betadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping were implemented.  
2. A midline vertical skin incision was made to cover the C3–C6 level. Paraspinal muscle dissection was performed to expose the bilateral laminae and lateral masses at C3–C6.  
3. Using a drill, pedicle screw entry points were created at the lateral margins of the bilateral C4 and C5 lateral masses. A 1 cm longitudinal skin incision was made 4 cm from the midline, bilaterally. A paramedian skin incision was prepared using a gearshift probe and hand drill for tapping, followed by uneventful pedicle screw insertion. (Vertex multi screw system, Medtronics, 18*3.5 (1ea), 22*3.5 (2ea), 24*3.5 (1ea). Subsequently, screw heads were connected using a rod and locked with a nut.)  
4. C4–C5 laminectomy was performed using Rounger and punch instruments. Ligamentum flavum was thoroughly removed to confirm the lateral margin of the thecal sac.  
5. Decortication was performed around the C4–C5 facet joints, followed by the application of autologous bone graft to promote bone fusion.  
6. Hemostasis was achieved using Surgicel (a hemostatic agent), and a single H-vac line was inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was performed.  
No changes were observed in the electroencephalogram (EEG) during surgery. The patient regained consciousness from anesthesia and was transferred to the recovery room.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: [DATE] 05:57"

Surgery Record: [HOSPITAL] (Spine & Joint Center) (DATE)  
Procedure: Posterior decompression, cervical spine; Posterior instrumentation with fusion with bone graft (iliac bone & local bone), cervical spine  
Preoperative Diagnosis:  
1. Compressive myelopathy, C3-4  
2. Spinal stenosis, C3-4-5-6  
Postoperative Diagnosis:  
1. Compressive myelopathy, C3-4  
2. Spinal stenosis, C3-4-5-6  
Name of Operation:  
1. Posterior decompression, C3-4-5-6  
2. Posterior instrumentation with fusion with bone graft (iliac bone & local bone), C3-4-5-6  
Operative Findings:  
1. Decompression revealed cord release with intact dural pulsation.  
2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear.  
Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. A C-arm was utilized to confirm the C4-5 level, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision above and below the C4-5 level. The fascia was divided, and the paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. A subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina posterior and facet joints of C3-4-5-6. The spinous processes of C3, C4, C5, and C6 were removed. With attention to cord compression and dural tear, a burr was used to remove the lamina of C3, C4, C5, and C6. Additional decompression was performed around the cord using punch techniques. Eight K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, and C6. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which guided the placement of the screws. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. A left iliac bone was harvested for bone graft preparation. Using a burr, the cortical bone of the lateral masses of C4-5-6-7 was decorticated, and the local bone was mixed with the iliac bone for grafting. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The wound was closed in layers and dressed occlusively to complete the procedure.  

Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Time of Writing: [DATE] [TIME]"

5. Subsequently, the laminae at C4 were thinned using drilling to an eggshell form. A Kerrison rongeur was used to perform laminectomy at C4 in a manner similar to the C3 laminectomy, achieving decompression. No kinking was observed at the C3–C4 junction, and the spinal cord appeared fully decompressed with normal pulsation.  
6. A H-vac 1 unit was used, and meticulous bleeding control was performed. Massive irrigation was carried out, and the wound was closed layer by layer.  
Intraoperative IOM showed no changes, and no other significant findings were noted. The patient was extubated and transferred to the PACU.

Procedure and Technique:  
* Preparation: General anesthesia applied. Patient placed in prone position without head fixation. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) utilized. Aseptic draping performed.  
* Approach:  
- C-arm used to confirm C3-C5 location, followed by midline skin incision covering C3-5 levels.  
- Neck muscles dissected midline to expose C3-5 spinous process tips.  
- Paraspinal muscles dissected subperiosteally to expose C4 lamina, C3 lower, and C5 upper lamina.  
- C4 laminectomy performed using drill and punch.  
- C3 lower and C5 upper lamina portions removed with punch, along with ligamentum flavum.  
- Exposed dura was slightly tense; decompression achieved after laminectomy and ligamentum flavum removal, as evidenced by mild bulging.  
* Closure:  
- J-P 100M insertion  
- Wound sutured according to anatomic layers  
* IOM Changes:  
- Initial Thenar Motor Evoked Potentials (MEP) showed lower amplitude on the left compared to the right. Post-decompression, both sides showed slight amplitude increases compared to baseline, but no significant recovery was observed. Bilateral amplitude differences remained similar. No other significant MEP/SEP changes noted.  
* Postoperative Extubation: Patient transferred to recovery room.

Intraoperative Findings: No significant changes in EP (electrophysiological) parameters observed.  
Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in prone position with neck flexion and head fixation. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by antiseptic preparation and aseptic draping.  
2. Palpation confirmed the C5-7 spinous processes, after which a midline linear skin incision was performed. Muscle dissection was conducted, followed by periosteal dissection to expose the C5-7 spinous processes and bilateral laminae.  
3. The outer cortical bone of the right lamina at C5-6 was drilled to create a gutter, while the outer cortical bone of the left lamina was drilled to form a hinge. The left gutter was opened, and a plate was used for fixation to perform an open door laminoplasty.  
4. Under microscopic visualization, the superior portion of the C7 lamina was removed in a dome shape to decompress the spinal cord.  
5. Hemostasis and irrigation were performed. A single H-vac was inserted, and the wound was closed in a layer-by-layer fashion. Surgery was concluded.  
Postoperative: The patient was transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit.

**Nerve Conduction Study (November 5, 2019):** No significant abnormalities suggestive of peripheral neuropathy.  
**Metabolic Panel:** Vitamin B12 1396 pg/mL, Folate 21.1 ng/mL, HbA1c 5.6.  
**Immunologic Panel:** Anti-GD1b(-), anti-GM1(-), anti-GQ1b(-), GM1(-).  

**Spine MRI (Cervical Extension and Flexion, November 12, 2019):**  
- Central canal stenosis at C3/4, C4/5, C5/6, and C6/7.  
- More pronounced on extension position due to ligamentum flavum buckling, central disc herniation/bulging, and retrolisthesis at C5/6/7.  
- Suspected cord signal change at C4/5.  

**Current Problem List**  
- Rule out cervical myelopathy:  
  - Spine MRI suggests cord signal change at C5 level.  
  - Surgical intervention may have limited efficacy.  
- Rule out Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS):  
  - 4/e distal dominant weakness and hypesthesia.  
  - Normal NCS findings.  
  - Low likelihood of GBS.  

**Future Treatment Plan**  
The patient was admitted to Neurology for evaluation of bilateral upper limb weakness, sensory abnormalities, and management. Initial workup, including metabolic, immunologic, and NCS studies, showed no abnormalities (NCS performed two weeks after symptom onset was also normal), reducing GBS likelihood. Cervical myelopathy was the only suspected diagnosis. Due to uncertainty regarding surgical intervention, the patient and family opted for observation. Persistent difficulty walking without assistance led to further imaging (spine MRI with extension/flexion and EP studies), confirming more severe stenosis. The patient and family provided surgical consent, and the case was referred for further treatment.  

**Patient Equipment/Devices Provided with the Patient**  
None specified.

Procedure and Technique:  
- Laminoplasty, C4-5 (Right side lamina open) & C6 upper partial laminectomy.  
  - Preparation: Patient placed in prone position on spine table. Three-point Mayfield fixator attached to skull. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) applied. Aseptic draping completed.  
  - Approach: C2-C7 palpation confirmed, followed by midline skin incision at C3-6 level. Neck muscles dissected midline to expose C3-6 spinous process tips. Paraspinal muscles dissected subperiosteally to expose C3-6 lamina.  
  - Main Procedure: High-speed drill used to create a hinge site on the left side and a gutter on the right side at the boundary of C4-C5 lamina and lateral mass. Lamina was retracted to the left side to achieve decompression, with the inferior portion of the open lamina partially removed using a dissector and punch to fully detach the dura from the lamina. C6 upper lamina was partially removed using a punch. Open door laminoplasty performed using a center piece plate and screw (Medtronics). No dura tear or hinge fracture observed across all levels.  
  - Closure: H-vac 1ea inserted, bellafuse placed over the plate. Wound closed in anatomic layers with sutures.  
Postoperative: Patient extubated and transferred to recovery.  
Instruments Used: OD plate, 10mm, 2 pieces; 2.6 SCREW, 5mm, 7 pieces; 3.0 SCREW, 7mm, 1 piece.

Surgical End Time: [DATE] 3:25 PM  
Intraoperative Notes:  
> Description  
1. Patient was placed in the prone position with slight neck flexion and head fixation using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) settings were established. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. After confirming the level with a C-arm, a midline skin incision was made across the C2-C6 spinous process level. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the C3-7 laminae to the lateral mass boundary.  
3. On the left side, the lamina lateral margins were removed sequentially from C3 to C6. A cutting burr was used to leave the inner bony shell intact, followed by a diamond burr for complete removal. A Penfield #4 dissector was used to confirm the dissection. On the right side, the cutting burr was used to leave only the inner bony shell, and the spinous process was adjusted to allow visible movement.  
4. The spinous process was shifted from left to right, creating a greenstick fracture. The C6 spinous process tip was cut with a burr to position it closer to the midline.  
5. A Medtronic 12mm x 4 centerpiece OD plate and Medtronic 2.6 Screw (2.6 x 5mm x 8) were utilized.  
6. Irrigation was performed, and hemovac drains were placed in both PVM gutters. Layer-by-layer wound closure was completed. No IOM changes occurred during the procedure.  
7. Post-extubation, the patient was transferred to the PACU.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: [DATE] 10:47 PM"

**Procedure:** Posterior decompression, cervical spine (Posterior Laminoplasty, C3-4-5)  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy  
**Anesthesia:** General  
**Surgery Date:** [DATE]  
**Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] 11:55 AM  
**Surgery End Time:** [DATE] 2:37 PM  
**Intraoperative Findings:**  
1. Preoperative status and diagnosis: #1. Compressive myelopathy, C3-4-5.  
2. Intraoperative findings: #1. Decompression revealed cord release with dural pulsation. #2. No findings of dural tear or other abnormalities. #3. Iliac bone graft harvested from the right posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS).  

**Operative Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Routine skin preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine. A C-arm was used to confirm the C3-4-5 level, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. Fascia was divided, and paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina posterior and facet joint at C3-4-5. The spinous processes of C3, C4, and C5 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear, with partial laminectomy performed on the right side using a burr. Additional decompression was achieved using punches. K-wires were inserted into the right lateral masses of C3, C4, and C5, and their positions were confirmed with a C-arm. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed. Iliac bone graft was harvested from the right PSIS. Cortical bone from the facet joints of C3-4-5 was decorticated, and a mixture of local bone and allograft was used for grafting. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac drains. The wound was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing. Surgery was concluded.  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Creation Time:** [DATE] 17:21"

> **Description:**  
1. After administering general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. The head was immobilized using a Mayfield head fixator in the neutral position. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was initiated. Aspetic draping was performed.  
2. Alignment was confirmed using a C-arm, and the C3-4 level was identified. A left paramedian vertical skin incision was made. A tubular retractor was attempted but could not be placed due to insufficient muscle split. The incision was extended slightly superiorly and inferiorly. The ossified bone at the surface of C3-4 was removed, and the muscles were dissected from the periosteum to expose the C3-4 spinous process. The lateral masses of C3-4 were exposed through muscle dissection.  
3. The lower portion of the C3 lamina and the upper portion of the C4 lamina were carefully removed using a punch. The lamina was removed down to the level of the dura (LF) to decompress the thecal sac. The C3-4 lateral masses were drilled to create a fusion bed, and autologous bone was placed as an onlay graft.  
4. Hemorrhage was controlled, and saline irrigation was performed to confirm the absence of bleeding. A H-vac was placed, and the wound was closed in layers.  
No significant intraoperative monitoring changes were observed. The patient was transferred to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU) after anesthesia was terminated.

Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in prone position using a horseshoe positioning device. A level check was performed using a C-arm fluoroscope, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline and vertical skin incision was made to include the C3-C6 levels. The midline musculature was dissected and detached to expose the bilateral laminae and spinous processes.  
3. A Ronger was used to remove the C4-5 spinous processes. Subsequently, a cutting burr, diamond burr, and punch were utilized to perform a total laminectomy at C4-5, along with removal of the ligamentum flavum. Spinal cord swelling was severe, but decompression resulted in adequate pulsation. To prevent spinal cord kinking, a laminectomy was performed on the lower half of C3 using the same method. A laminectomy was also performed on the upper half of C6.  
4. Irrigation was performed, and a single closed drain was inserted. The wound was closed in layers, and the surgery was concluded.  
5. Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the recovery room.

  - **Procedure:**  
    - **Preparation:** Patient was placed in a prone position on a general table. Mayfield fixator was used for skull fixation. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was set up. Skin preparation and aseptic draping were performed. IOM showed a 50% reduction in bilateral thenar motor evoked potentials (MEPs).  
    - **Approach:**  
      - C2 and C7 landmarks were confirmed via palpation. A midline skin incision was made to cover the C2-C7 level, followed by midline dissection to expose the C3-C7 spinous process tips. C4-5-6 spinous processes were identified.

      - C-arm imaging was used to confirm the level.  
    - **Laminoplasty Technique:**  
      - C4-5-6 interspinous ligament was removed. Using a drill and punch, the right side of the C4-5-6 laminae was opened, while the left side was fashioned as a hinge.  
      - C4-5-6 laminae were secured with a 10mm plate.  
    - **Closure:**  
      - Hemostasis and irrigation were performed. A H-vac suction device was inserted. The wound was closed in anatomical layers with sutures.  
- **Postoperative Course:** Patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room. No significant intraoperative EP changes were noted.

Postoperative Diagnosis: Herniated Intervertebral Disc Disease of the Cervical Spine with Radiculopathy

Operative Technique and Findings:  
Description: Preoperative Status and Diagnosis:  
1. Herniated Intervertebral Disc (HIVD), C4-5-6-7  
2. Compressive Myelopathy, C4-5-6-7  
Anesthesia: General  
Name of Operation:  
1. Posterior Decompression, C4-5-6-7  
2. Posterior Instrumentation with Fusion with Bone Graft (Iliac Bone & Local Bone), C4-5-6  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same as Above  
Operative Findings:  
1. After Decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
2. Sufficient decompression was performed around the right-sided root exit foramen at C6-7.  
3. No intraoperative findings of dural tear were observed.  

Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C5-6 level was confirmed, and a midline longitudinal skin incision was made below and above C5-6. The fascia was divided, and paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina posteriorly and facet joints, revealing the C4-5-6-7 facet joints. The spinous processes of C4, C5, and C6 were removed, and care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C4, C5, and C6. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches, and sufficient decompression was achieved on the right side of C7. Six K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C4, C5, and C6, and their positions were confirmed using a C-arm. Lateral mass screws were then inserted based on these findings. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. Subsequently, the left iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. The cortical bone of the lateral masses at C4-5-6 was decorticated using a burr, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac lines. A single JP drain was inserted at the iliac bone harvest site. The wound was closed in layers and dressed with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure.  

Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Time of Writing: [DATE]"

**Description:** Preoperative Status and Diagnosis:  
1. Cervical myelopathy at C2–C3–C4–C5–C6  
**Anesthesia:** General  
**Name of Operation:**  
1. Posterior decompression via laminectomy at C2–C3–C4–C5–C6  
2. Posterior instrumentation with fusion using bone graft (iliac bone and local bone) at C2–C3–C4–C5–C6  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Same as above  
**Operative Findings:**  
1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
2. The surgery was performed under SEP (somatosensory evoked potential) and MEP (motor evoked potential) monitoring; no abnormal SEP or MEP findings were observed during the procedure.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine. A C-arm was used to confirm the C2–C3–C4–C5–C6 level, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. The fascia was divided, and paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina and facet joints at C2–C3–C4–C5–C6. The spinous processes at C3–C4–C5 were removed, and care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the lamina at C3–C4–C5. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, and C6. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which were then referenced for screw placement. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. The right iliac bone was harvested for bone graft preparation. The cortical bone of the lateral masses at C2–C6 was decorticated using a burr, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac lines. A single JP drain was inserted at the iliac bone harvest site. The surgical site was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure.  

**Supplies:**  
- Thrombin: 2 units  
- Spongostan: 4 units  
- Guardix: 6 mL (hemostatic agent)

Intraoperative Notes: Surgical Technique and Findings  
Description: Under general anesthesia, baseline somatosensory evoked potentials (SEP) and motor evoked potentials (MEP) were measured prior to placing the patient in the prone position. The SEP showed reduced amplitude across all limbs, while the MEP demonstrated low amplitude in the bilateral deltoid muscles, with no other significant findings. The patient was placed in the prone position after wearing a cervical orthosis.  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned in the prone position with head fixation. Intraoperative EP monitoring was applied, and aseptic draping was performed.  
2. A midline skin incision was made, followed by paraspinal muscle splitting and exposure of the C3-5 spinous process tip. A C-arm was used for level confirmation.  
3. Using a Penfield dissector No. 1, the muscle attached to the lamina was detached, and dissection was performed around the interlaminar space using a monopolar cautery to isolate the multifidus muscle. The entire lamina of C3-4 was exposed.  
4. The C3-4 spinous processes were removed using a rongeur, and the lower part of the bilateral C3 lamina and the upper part of the C4 lamina were removed with a punch to expose the spinal cord. The cord was pale and swollen. Adequate cord decompression and satisfactory dural sac pulsation were confirmed. Surgicel (a surgical hemostatic agent) and Floseal (a tissue adhesive) were applied for hemostasis.  
5. After massive saline irrigation and hemostasis, two hemovac lines were inserted, and the wound was closed in layers. No intraoperative monitoring (IOM) changes were noted.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Time of Writing: [DATE] 7:25 PM"

Procedure: Posterior decompression of the cervical spine, iliac bone graft (C3-4-5-6)

Anesthesia Type: General  
Surgery Date: DATE  
Surgeon: [NAME]  
Assistant: [NAME]  
Surgical Record: Orthopedic Surgery (Joint and Spine Center) (DATE)  
Procedure: Posterior decompression of the cervical spine, iliac bone graft (C3-4-5-6)  
Preoperative Diagnosis: Cervical myelopathy, spinal cord edema  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Spinal cord edema, cervical myelopathy  
Anesthesia: General  
Name of Operation:  
1. Posterior decompression of the cervical spine (C3-4-5-6)  
2. Posterior instrumentation with fusion using bone graft (iliac bone and local bone), cervical spine (C3-4-5-6)  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same as above  
Operative Findings:  
1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released and dural pulsations were confirmed.  
Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. A C-arm was utilized to confirm the C3-4-5-6 vertebral levels. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made below the C4-5 level, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints of the C3-4-5-6 levels. The spinous processes of C3, C4, C5, and C6 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C3, C4, C5, and C6. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. Eight K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, and C6. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which were then referenced for screw placement. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed. The left iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. The cortical bone of the lateral masses at C3-4-5-6 was decorticated using a burr, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac drains were inserted, and one JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. Layered closure was performed, followed by occlusive dressing, and the surgery was concluded.  
Described by R1. [NAME] M.D.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Date: DATE"

**Anesthesia:** General

2. Posterior instrumentation with fusion using autologous bone graft (local bone), C3-C4-C5-C6-C7  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Same as above  
**Operative Findings:**  
1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C3-C4-C5-C6-C7 levels were identified. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made below C4 and above C5. The fascia was divided, and the paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the C3-C4-C5-C6-C7 facet joints. The spinous processes of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae at C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. Ten K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites. Based on this, lateral mass screws were inserted. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. The left iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. The cortical bone of the lateral masses at C3-C4-C5-C6-C7 was decorticated using a burr, and the autologous bone graft was placed. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemovac drainage lines were inserted. The wound was closed in layers and dressed with an occlusive dressing to complete the surgery.

Intraoperative Findings:  
- Decompressive Laminectomy, C3 (Partial); Laminoplasty (Left Open), C4 & C6  
Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. After administering general anesthesia and positioning the patient in prone position with head fixation, the C2-7 level was confirmed using a C-arm. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. The C2-6 level was confirmed using a C-arm, and a vertical midline skin incision was performed to include this level. The paraspinal muscles were dissected subperiosteally to expose the C3-6 laminae, with removal of the spinous processes and interspinous ligaments.  
3. A partial laminectomy was performed at the lower 2/3 of C3 using a drill and punch. The lamina and lateral mass boundary at the left side of C4 was opened using a drill and punch, followed by a laminectomy at C5. The lamina and lateral mass boundary at the left side of C6 was similarly opened. The exposed dural sac showed mild dorsal bulging under elevated pressure, but pulsation normalized after laminectomy.  
4. A hinge side was formed at the right lamina and lateral mass boundary of C4 and C6 using a drill, followed by laminoplasty using a plate and screws. No hinge side fracture occurred.  
5. Meticulous saline irrigation was performed, and bleeding control was achieved using Floseal (surgical adhesive). A Hemovac drain was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers.  
Intraoperative IOM showed no abnormalities. The patient was extubated and transferred to PACU.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]

> 2. Ossification of the Posterior Longitudinal Ligament (OPLL) at C2-3-4-5, T1-2

> 3. EP Monitoring was performed, but no abnormalities were noted.  

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the levels C2-3-4-5-6 were confirmed. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints up to C2-3-4. The spinous processes at C3, C4, C5, and C6 were removed, and the laminae at these levels were removed using a burr while carefully avoiding cord compression and dural tear. Additional decompression was performed using punches around the spinal cord. Three K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C4, C5, and C6, and the lateral mass screw insertion sites were confirmed using a C-arm. The cervical lordosis was respected, and the rod was bent for instrumentation. Local bone and allograft were used for grafting. The incision was extended distally to access T1 and T2 levels, and the facet joints at these levels were exposed using the same method. The laminae at T1 and T2 were removed using a burr, and further decompression was performed with punches. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, and two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The wound was closed in layers and dressed with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure."

Anesthesia: General

1. Posterior decompression of the cervical spine (C7-T1)

Postoperative Diagnosis: Same as above  
Operative Findings:  
1. Severe cord compression observed; decompression revealed a distended dura.

Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C7-T1 level was confirmed. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made above C7-T1, and fascia was divided. Paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the C7-T1 facet joint. The spinous process at C7-T1 was removed, and a total laminectomy was performed with caution for cord compression and dural tear. During posterior decompression, severe cord compression was observed, with distended dura noted. A single K-wire was inserted into each lateral mass of C7-T1, and the lateral mass screw insertion sites were confirmed using a C-arm. Lateral mass screws were then inserted based on this confirmation. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation.  
Following this, the right iliac bone was harvested to prepare the bone graft. Using a burr, cortical bone from the lateral masses of C7-T1 was decorticated, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with iliac bone.  
Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The wound was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing to complete the surgery.

Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in a prone position with Mayfield head fixation. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied. Skin antiseptics and aseptic draping were performed. A midline skin incision was made at the C3-C6 level after palpation of the C3-C6 region and confirmation with a C-arm. Neck muscles were dissected midline to expose the C3-C6 spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection using a Bovie was performed to expose the C3-C6 spinous processes and laminae.  
Main Procedure:  
A V-point was identified using a Penfield #4 retractor. A cutting burr and punch were used to open the C4-6 right lamina. The left side was similarly prepared with a V-point and cutting burr to create a gutter. The right lamina was elevated, and the ligamentum flavum was removed. The C4-6 ligamentum flavum was excised using a punch. After confirming complete decompression of the thecal sac, a Medtronic centerpiece plate was secured to the laminae. Prominent C4-6 spinous processes were partially removed using a cutting burr.  
Closure: A 1-lumen H-vac was inserted, and the wound was closed in anatomic layers with sutures. Postoperatively, the patient was extubated and transferred to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU).

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
**Description:**  
**Preoperative Status and Diagnosis:**  
1. Cervical myelopathy due to HIVD at C4-5, 5-6, 6-7  
2. Spinal stenosis at L3-4-5-S1 with severe foraminal stenosis at L4-5, 5-S1 (right side)  
**Anesthesia:** General  
**Name of Operation:**  
1. Posterior instrumentation and fixation of the left C3-4-5-6-7  
2. Posterior instrumentation and fixation of the right C4-5-7  
3. Partial laminectomy of C3 and C7  
4. Total laminectomy of C4, 5, 6  
5. Iliac bone graft (right side)  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Same as above  
**Operative Findings:**  
1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear were observed.  
3. During pedicle screw insertion at right C3 and C6, bone resistance was insufficient, leading to a crack; fixation was not performed.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C3-4-5-6-7 level was confirmed, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision and fascia division. Paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina posterior and facet joints of C3-4-5-6-7. The spinous processes at C4-5-6 were removed, and decompression was performed cautiously to avoid cord compression and dural tear using a burr for partial laminectomy at C3 and C7, and total laminectomy at C4, 5, 6. Additional decompression was achieved using a punch. K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3-4-5-6-7. The lateral mass screw insertion sites were confirmed with a C-arm. Lateral mass screws were then inserted, but during screw placement at right C3 and C6, bone cracks occurred, necessitating screw removal. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. Right iliac bone was harvested for bone graft preparation. Cortical bone from the lateral masses of C3-4-5-6-7 was decorticated using a burr, and local bone was mixed with iliac bone for grafting. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac lines. The wound was closed in layers and secured with an occlusive dressing.  
**Authored by:** [NAME]

- Prima OCT screw 3.5 x 12mm (5 pieces)  
- Prima OCT screw 3.5 x 14mm (3 pieces)  
- Rod (80mm, 60mm)  
- Genesis sponge block  
- Thrombin  
- Guardix

Intraoperative Notable Findings:  
> Description  
Preoperative Diagnosis:  
1. Cervical myelopathy, C5-6-7  
Name of Operation: Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion, C5-6-7 with allogenic bone graft, iliac bone graft (mini-incision); Atlantis plate fixation, C5-6-7  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same as above  
Operative Findings:  
1. A herniated disc at C5-6-7 was observed to be compressing the spinal cord. A thorough decompression was performed.  
2. During decompression, the ligamentum flavum was found to be severely adhered to the spinal cord. Due to the risk of cord injury, it could not be completely removed, and only the maximum feasible removal was performed.  
3. No definite neurovascular stricture, trachea, esophagus, or spinal cord dura injury occurred during the procedure.  
Operative Procedure:  
The patient was placed under general anesthesia in the supine position with the neck in a neutral position. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed.  
After confirming the C5-6-7 level with a C-arm, a transverse skin incision of approximately 3 cm was made on the anterior left side. The platysma muscle was transversely incised and dissected, retracting the trachea and esophagus to the right and the left longus coli muscle to the left to expose the C5-6 vertebral body and disc. The vertebral body was palpated, and a needle was inserted into the disc space for confirmation via portable X-ray.  
The C5-6-7 disc space was exposed, and a microscopic discectomy was performed. A mini-incision was used to harvest iliac cancellous bone graft, which was then cut to fit the disc space and inserted for fusion. Subsequently, an anterior plate was fixed at C5-6-7 under C-arm guidance.  
Massive irrigation and hemostasis were performed, followed by Hemovac suction. The wound was closed in layers, and a Philadelphia brace was applied.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Date of Writing: [DATE] at 11:42 AM"

**Intraoperative Findings:** No surgical findings > LP, C3-6, C7 dome (C3 laminectomy).  
**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. General anesthesia was administered, and the patient was positioned prone with slight neck flexion and head fixation using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) settings were established. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. A midline skin incision was made across the C2-C7 spinous process level, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose the C3-6 lamina to the boundary with the lateral masses.  
3. At C3, the spinous process was removed using a rongeur, and drilling was performed before detaching the dura. A punch was used to perform laminectomy.  
4. The upper lamina of C7 was removed using a punch to complete the C7 dome plasty.  
5. The interspinous ligament was removed using a rongeur. A gutter was created using a drill at the boundary between the left C4-6 lamina and lateral mass. The boundary was cut using a drill and punch, and the ligamentum flavum was removed to confirm the dural sac.  
6. The posterior arch was elevated and fixed with three titanium plates to complete the open-door laminoplasty at C4-6.  
7. Irrigation was performed, and a Hemovac drain was inserted. The wound was closed layer by layer.  
8. The patient was extubated and transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU). No IOM changes occurred during the procedure.  
**Instrumentation:** Osteosynthetic Device Plate, 10mm, [ORG], 3 pieces; 2.6 screw, 5mm, [ORG], 12 pieces.

**Intraoperative Notes**:  
> **Description**:  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position with the neck slightly flexed and head immobilized using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was set up. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. A midline skin incision was made across the C2-C7 spinous process level, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose the bilateral C3-6 laminae to the lateral mass boundary.  
3. C2 undercutting was performed to widen the space, and a trough was created on the Lt C3-6 lamina-lateral mass boundary using a drill. A similar trough was made on the Rt C3-6 lamina-lateral mass boundary to allow for manipulation. The Lt C3-6 lamina-lateral mass boundary was cut using a drill and punch, and the ligamentum flavum was removed to expose the dural sac. The C2-3 interspinous ligament was removed using a pituitary forcep and punch. Bilateral C7 upper laminotomy was performed, and the ligamentum flavum was removed to ensure adequate space.  
4. The laminotomy site was secured with a 12mm centralizing plate to complete the open door laminoplasty at C3-6.  
5. Hemostasis and massive irrigation were performed. Bleeding was noted in the C2 laminotomy area and the lateral mass drill site, which was controlled using two Floseal applications. After irrigation and HVAC insertion, the wound was closed in layers.  
6. The patient was transferred to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU).  
**Author**: [NAME]  
**Time Written**: [DATE] 6:41:00 PM"

Using a C-arm, the C4–C5–C6–C7 level was confirmed. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made above and below the level, and the fascia was divided. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous processes and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints of C4–C5–C6–C7. After removing the spinous processes, the spinal cord compression and dural tear were carefully monitored, and the laminae at each level were removed using a burr. Additional decompression of the spinal cord was performed using punches. Eight K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C4, C5, C6, and C7. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which were then referenced for screw placement. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. A right iliac bone graft was harvested and prepared. The cortical bone of the lateral masses at C4–C5–C6–C7 was decorticated using a burr, and the local bone graft and iliac bone graft were mixed and implanted. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, and two Hemovac drains were inserted. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone graft site. The surgical site was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing to complete the procedure.

Operative Findings:  
1. Decompression revealed release of the spinal cord with visible dural pulsation.

Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the levels C3-4-5-6-7-T1 were confirmed. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made superior-inferior, and fascia was divided. Paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the facet joints of C4-5-6-7-T1. The spinous processes of C4, C5, C6, C7, and T1 were removed. With attention to cord compression and dural integrity, a burr was used to remove the laminae of C4, C5, C6, C7, and T1. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punch techniques. Two K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, C6, C7, and T1. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, and screws were placed accordingly. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis for instrumentation. Iliac bone was harvested for bone graft preparation. Using a burr, cortical bone from the lateral masses of C3-4-5-6-7 was decorticated, and the graft was combined with local bone and iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by insertion of two Hemo-vac lines. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. Layer-by-layer closure was performed, and occlusive dressing was applied to complete the surgery.

> #2. Posterior instrumentation, Cervical spine (C3-4-5-6-7), lateral mass screw and rod  
> #3. Iliac bone graft  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same as above  
Operative Findings:  
> #1. After decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
> #2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear were observed.  
Operative Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position, and routine preparation and draping were performed for the Cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the levels of C2-3-4-5-6-7 were confirmed, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. The fascia was divided, and the paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina and facet joints of C2-3-4-5-6-7. The spinous processes of C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed. With attention to cord compression and dural tear, the lamina of C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed using a burr. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches. Two K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7, and the C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites. These sites were referenced for screw insertion. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed. The right iliac bone was harvested for bone graft preparation. Using a burr, the cortical bone of the lateral masses of C3-4-5-6-7 was decorticated. The local bone and iliac bone were mixed and grafted. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac lines. A single JP drain was inserted at the iliac bone harvest site. Layer-by-layer closure was performed, and occlusive dressing was applied to complete the surgery.  
Thrombin 1ea, Guardix 6g 1ea

Orthopedics (Joint and Spine Center) ([DATE])  
**Procedure:** Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion, C4-5-6; anterior decompression, spine  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:**  
1. Cervical myelopathy  
2. Herniated intervertebral disc (HIVD), C4-5-6-7  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Same as above  
**Operative Findings:**  
1. An anterior approach was performed, revealing severe disc herniation at C4/5/6 levels. The spinal cord was severely compressed. All discs were completely removed.  
2. Tri-cortical block allograft bone was inserted into the C4/5/6 disc space.  
**Operative Procedure:**  
The patient was placed in a supine position under general anesthesia. Aseptic technique was employed, and the anterior neck area was draped. The thyroid cartilage and upper margin of the clavicle were palpated to estimate the vertebral level. A transverse incision was made, and layers were deepened. The platysma was dissected, with the longus colli and carotid artery retracted laterally, and the trachea/esophagus retracted medially to expose the C4/5/6 vertebral bodies and intervertebral disc space. Using pituitary forceps and a curette, disc material compressing the spinal cord was thoroughly removed to achieve decompression. The spinal cord was severely compressed by the herniated disc, and decompression resulted in partial recovery of pulsation. Tri-cortical block allograft bone was inserted into the C4/5/6 disc space. Meticulous hemostasis was performed. C-arm imaging confirmed alignment of the cervical vertebral body and bone block. After massive irrigation, layers were sutured sequentially, and two lines of hemovac drains were inserted to complete the surgical procedure.  
**Materials Used:**  
- Tri-cortical block allograft bone: 1 piece  
- Spongostan: 2 pieces  
- Thrombin: 1 piece  
- Guardix: 3g, 1 piece

> #1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position and secured with a Mayfield frame. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine.  
> #2. The level was marked using a C-arm, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision and fascia division.  
> #3. Paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the facet joint, after which the spinous process was removed using a bone cutter.  
> #4. An incision was made on the right iliac crest for iliac bone harvesting. Cancellous bone was maximized and separately preserved.  
> #5. Using a rongeur and punch, the C3-4 spinous process and PLC were removed. Pedicle screws were inserted, and a rod was bent to match the normal lordosis and inserted.  
> #6. A partial laminectomy was performed on the C5 lamina.  
> #7. Nuts were applied, and the rod was fixed using a driver to complete instrumentation.  
> #8. The harvested iliac cancellous autograft was positioned in the lateral mass area, and a trimmed local autograft was also inserted.  
> #9. After irrigation, a drain was inserted, and the wound was sutured layer by layer.  
> #10. Occlusive dressing was applied. The area where the Mayfield frame was applied was disinfected with betadine gauze, followed by gauze and EB dressing.

- The same procedure was repeated for the right side, with three K-wires inserted and C-arm fluoroscopy used to confirm the levels before lateral mass screw insertion.  
- A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed.  
- Autologous bone grafting was conducted using IBG. Bone grafting was completed using IBG and DBM.  
- Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. Two Hemovac drains were inserted.  
- Layer-by-layer closure was performed, followed by an occlusive dressing. The procedure was concluded.

Cortical bone from the lateral masses of C3-4-5-6 was decorticated using a burr, and a mixture of local bone and iliac bone was used for grafting. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac lines. A single JP drain was placed at the iliac bone harvest site. The wound was closed in layers and covered with an occlusive dressing to complete the surgery.

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia, and a Mayfield head holder was applied. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the C3-4 level was confirmed, followed by a midline longitudinal skin incision. The incision was extended upward and downward gradually. During soft tissue dissection, the approach was performed to detach the paraspinal muscles from the spinous process and interspinous ligament, exposing the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was carried out to expose the C3-4 facet joint. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear, with total laminectomy performed at C3 and partial laminectomy at C4. Fusion was then carried out at C3-4. The spinal cord and roots were confirmed to be free. A right iliac bone graft (IBG) was harvested. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-Vac drains. Layer-by-layer closure was completed, and occlusive dressings were applied to conclude the surgery.

Intraoperative Findings:  
> Preoperative Status and Diagnosis:  
#1. Compressive Myelopathy, C3-4-5-6-7  
#2. Compressive Myelopathy, T12-L1  
Anesthesia: General  
Operation Name:  
#1. Posterior Decompression by Laminectomy, C3-4-5-6-7  
#2. Posterior Instrumentation with Fusion Using Bone Graft, C3-4-5-6-7  
#3. Posterior Decompression by Laminectomy, T11-T12-L1-L2  
#4. Posterior Instrumentation with Fusion Using Bone Graft, T11-T12-L1-L2  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same as Above  
Operative Findings:  
#1. Decompression revealed cord release and confirmed dural pulsation.  
#2. No intraoperative findings of dural tear.  
#3. At T11-T12-L1-L2 site, previous L1 laminectomy resulted in severe scar tissue adhesion, requiring adhesiolysis.  
Surgical Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in prone position. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed for cervical and thoracolumbar spine. Using a C-arm, C3-4-5-6-7 level was confirmed, followed by midline longitudinal skin incision and fascia division. Paraspinal muscles were detached from spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose C3-4-5-6-7 facet joints. Spinous processes of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 were removed. With attention to cord compression and dural tear, burr was used for total laminectomy of C4, C5, C6, and partial laminectomy of C3 and C7. Additional decompression was performed using punch around the cord. K-wires were inserted into lateral masses of C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7. C-arm confirmed lateral mass screw insertion sites, followed by screw placement. Pedicle screws were inserted into C7 bilateral. A rod was bent to match cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed. Cortical bone of lateral masses at C3-4-5-6-7 was decorticated using burr. Local bone and allograft were mixed and used for grafting. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by insertion of two hemostatic drainage devices. Layered closure was performed with occlusive dressing.  

For T11-T12-L1-L2, C-arm confirmed the level, followed by midline longitudinal skin incision and fascia division. Paraspinal muscles were detached to expose spinous processes, and subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose facet joints. Spinous processes of T11-T12-L1-L2 were removed, with attention to cord compression and dural tear. Burr was used for total laminectomy of T12 and partial laminectomy of L2. Adhesiolysis was performed for severe scar tissue adhesion from prior L1 laminectomy. Additional decompression was performed using punch. Pedicle screws were inserted bilaterally at T11-T12-L1-L2, followed by rod instrumentation. Cortical bone of facet joints at T11-T12-L1-L2 was decorticated using burr. Local bone and allograft were mixed and used for grafting. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by insertion of two hemostatic drainage devices. Layered closure was performed with occlusive dressing, and surgery was concluded.

Cervical myelopathy

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
- No intraoperative findings of dural tear.  
- After decompression, the spinal cord was released, and dural pulsation was confirmed.  
- Thrombin * 2 ea, Spongostan * 2 ea, Floseal 5ml * 1 ea, GS medical 3.5 cortical screw 12mm * 4 ea, GS medical Rod 40mm * 2 ea, GS medical Nut * 4 ea  

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in the prone position. Standard techniques were used for skin preparation and draping of the cervical spine. Using a C-arm, the cervical spine level was confirmed, and a midline longitudinal skin incision was made above and below the level. The fascia was divided, and the paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the lamina and facet joints of C3, C6, and C7. The spinous processes of C3 and C6 were removed, and care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C3, C6, and C7. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using a punch. Four K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C6 and C7, and their positions were confirmed using a C-arm. Lateral mass screws were then inserted based on these findings. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed. The right iliac bone was harvested for bone graft preparation. The cortical bone of the lateral masses of C6-7 was decorticated using a burr, and the graft was prepared by mixing local bone with iliac bone. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, and two Hemo-vac lines were inserted. Layer-by-layer closure was performed, followed by occlusive dressing, and the surgery was concluded.  

**Author:** [NAME] / [NAME]

- Intraoperative Findings:

  2. Electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring performed intraoperatively without abnormal findings.  
  3. No intraoperative dural tear or neurovascular injury observed.  
**Surgical Technique:**  
1. Patient placed in prone position under general anesthesia. Standard skin preparation and draping performed for the cervical spine.  
2. Midline longitudinal incision made at C3-C7 level using surface anatomy. Fascia divided.  
3. Paraspinal muscles detached from spinous processes and interspinous ligaments to expose spinous processes. Subperiosteal dissection performed to expose C3-4-5-6-7 facet joints.  
4. Level check performed using a C-arm.  
5. Spinous process at C3 removed. Laminectomy performed at C3 with caution for cord compression and dural tear using a burr. Additional decompression performed around the cord using punches.  
6. Laminoplasty performed at C4. Total laminectomy at C5, posterior decompression at C6-7. Lateral mass screw insertion sites confirmed at C5-6-7. Rod bent to match cervical lordosis and instrumentation performed.  
7. Uncoforaminotomy performed at C3-4-5 (Right). Autobone graft harvested from the Right iliac bone crest and augmented at the fusion site.  
8. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis performed. Two Hemo-Vac lines inserted.  
9. Layered closure performed, followed by occlusive dressing. Surgery concluded.

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
- Using a burr, partial laminectomy was performed at C5, C6, and C7, followed by central decompression. Adequate decompression was confirmed.  
- No significant neurological injury occurred during the procedure.  

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine.  
2. A midline longitudinal skin incision was made at the C5-6 level using a C-arm for guidance, and the fascia was divided.  
3. The paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the laminae and facet joints at C5-6-7.  
4. The spinous processes at C5 and C6 were removed. With caution for cord compression and dural tear, a burr, rounger, and bone cutter were used to remove the laminae at C5, C6, and C7. Additional decompression was performed around the spinal cord using punches.  
5. An uncoforaminotomy was performed on the left side at C6-7.  
6. Five K-wires were inserted into the lateral masses of C5 and C6 on both sides and C7 on the right. A C-arm was used to confirm the lateral mass screw insertion sites, which were then used for screw placement.  
7. A 45-degree pedicle at the left side of C7 was punctured with a K-wire, and the screw insertion site was confirmed using a C-arm.  
8. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis, and instrumentation was performed.  
9. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed, followed by the insertion of two Hemo-vac lines.  
10. The layers were closed sequentially, and an occlusive dressing was applied to conclude the surgery.

> Procedure: #. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia. Standard skin preparation and draping were performed for the cervical spine. #. The C3 and C7 levels were identified using surface anatomy, followed by a midline longitudinal incision. Fascia was divided. #. Paraspinal muscles were detached from the spinous process and interspinous ligament to expose the spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the C5-6 facet joint. #. Level confirmation was conducted using a C-arm. #. The spinous processes of C5 and C6 were removed. Care was taken to avoid cord compression and dural tear while using a burr to remove the laminae of C5 and C6. #. Additional decompression was performed around the cord using a punch. Total laminectomy was completed at C5, and partial laminectomy was performed at C6. #. A calcification observed in the interlaminar area of C5-C6 on MRI was identified as compressing the right side of the cord and was removed. Cord pulsation was confirmed after laminectomy. #. Lateral mass screw insertion sites were identified on both lateral masses of C5 and C6, and lateral mass screws were inserted. #. Autologous iliac bone graft was harvested from the right ilium and placed into the disc space. #. A rod was bent to match the cervical lordosis and instrumentation was performed. #. Copious irrigation and meticulous hemostasis were performed. One Hemo-vac drain was inserted. #. Layer-by-layer closure was performed, followed by an occlusive dressing. #. The L4–5 and S1 levels were confirmed, and a marking was made. A spinal needle was used to position the needle tip at the foramen. Dye was injected to confirm the needle tip was in the epidural space. #. Dexamethasone and lidocaine mixture was injected.

Surgery End Time: [DATE] 11:40:00 AM  
Intraoperative Notes:  
> Description  
1. Under general anesthesia, patient was placed in prone position with head flexed and 3-pin head fixation. Standard aseptic draping was performed. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied.  
2. Midline skin incision was performed, followed by paraspinal muscle dissection to expose the C2-5 lamina. The C2 musculature included detachment of the interspinalis muscle and partial capitis muscle, while most muscles inserting on the lamina were preserved. The multifidus muscle was stripped from C5 to expose the C3-5 lamina.  
3. The C3 and C4 laminae were prepared using a 3mm cutting burr to create the left-sided bony gutter, with 1mm punch to remove bone and achieve an open configuration. The right side was symmetrically prepared with a 3mm burr, resulting in a greenstick fracture.  
4. Following partial removal of the ligamentum flavum between C4-5 via punch, a 10mm double-bend plate (Metronic, Centerpiece) was used to stabilize the C3 and C4 laminae. (Screws used were 5mm and 7mm in size.)  
5. After extensive saline irrigation and meticulous hemostasis, a single JP drain was placed, and the wound was closed in layers.  
6. The patient remained stable throughout the procedure, with no abnormalities noted on IOM. The patient was transferred to the recovery room postoperatively.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: [DATE] 11:46 AM"
}

> Description  
1. Patient was placed in supine position with head fixation and aseptic draping completed. C-arm imaging was used to confirm the surgical level, and a 3 cm vertical incision was made on the paramedian right side. A tubular retractor was utilized to expose the C4,5 right lamina. C-arm imaging was repeated to verify the level. Ipsilateral C4 lamina drilling was performed, followed by removal of the lamina and flavum using a punch. Under microscope tilting, the contralateral lamina was drilled parallel to the contralateral lamina, leaving only the inner shell and removing the ligament with a Kerrison punch. The same procedure was performed on C5. The dural sac was exposed, and lateral margin was confirmed to ensure adequate decompression.  
2. Copious saline irrigation was performed, followed by layer-by-layer wound closure.

Intraoperative Notes:  
> Description  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in prone position with head fixation using a Mayfield frame. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline, vertical skin incision was performed to include the C3-4 level, with dissection and detachment of the muscles to expose both laminae and the spinous process.  
3. A high-speed drill was used to create a lamina drilling at C3 and C4 levels. The right side was prepared as a hinge site, while the left side was fashioned into a gutter. Using a dissector and punch, the gutter side (left side) was opened to expose the dura. A center piece plate (10mm) and screws (Medtronics) were utilized for fixation, performing an open-door laminoplasty.  
4. Irrigation was performed, and a single closed drain was inserted. The wound was closed in layers, and the procedure was concluded.  
Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the recovery room. No significant IOM changes occurred during the procedure.  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia, with the head positioned using a head rest. Bethadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping were performed.  
2. After confirming the level with a C-arm imaging device, a midline skin incision was made to fully cover the C5-6 level. The trapezius, splenius capitis, and semispinalis muscles were dissected to expose the C5-6 spinous process tip.  
3. From the spinous process tip, periosteal dissection was performed along the lamina, dissecting the multifidus muscles and other surrounding tissues to expose the C5-6 lamina. The level was reconfirmed using a C-arm imaging device.  
4. A 3mm cutting burr was used for drilling and punching to create a gutter on the right side. A similar procedure was performed on the left side, with the right lamina fractured in a green stick manner to fold it laterally. No hinge fracture was observed.  
5. A Centerpiece OD plate (Medtronic, 10mm, 2 units) was secured to the C5-6 level using screws.  
   - Centerpiece OD plate, Medtronic, 10mm, 2 units  
   - Centerpiece screws, Medtronic, 2.6 x 5mm, 8 units  
6. A single H-vac device was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers. The patient was extubated. Due to comorbidities, the patient was transferred to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU).  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 7:32 AM"

1. Patient placed in prone position under general anesthesia. Fixation was achieved using a Mayfield fixator, followed by intraoperative electrophysiological monitoring. Bethadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping were performed.  
2. C-arm and palpation confirmed C4 and C5 levels. A midline skin incision was made to cover C3-6 levels, followed by bilateral paraspinal muscle dissection to expose C4,5 spinous processes and laminae. A cerebellar retractor was installed, and lateral C-arm imaging confirmed the level.  
3. On the left side, the C5 lamina lower margin was dissected using a Penfield #4 dissector, and a 2mm sliding Kerrison punch was used to cut between the lamina and lateral mass. The ligament undersurface between C3-4 laminae was dissected, and the ligament was removed using a Kerrison punch.  
4. The same approach was applied to the right side to remove the lamina lateral margin and eliminate the ligament between C5-6 laminae.  
5. After the lamina flap gained mobility, the spinous process was elevated, and soft tissue beneath the lamina flap was dissected using a Penfield #3 dissector to remove C4,5 laminae en bloc. Bleeding from the dural vessels at the laminectomy left margin was controlled with bipolar coagulation. A bony mass identified on CT/MR was visible on the inner surface of the lamina flap.  
6. Saline irrigation was performed to control bleeding, and a hemovac was placed for wound repair in layers. No significant intraoperative IOM changes were observed. The patient was transferred to the recovery room post-extubation.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 9:56 PM"
}

Procedure and Technique:  
* Preparation: Patient was placed in prone position on a general anesthesia table. Skull fixation was performed using a Mayfield fixator. IOM was set up. Skin preparation and aseptic draping were completed.

- C3-4 lamina was removed using a cutting burr, diamond burr, and punch. During right-sided laminectomy, transient EMG activity was detected in the right deltoid muscle but resolved quickly.  
- A partial laminectomy was performed on the C2 lower region using a punch. Posterior dural bulging was noted.  
- C5-6 lamina on the right side was opened using a drill and punch. The left side was prepared with a hinge using a drill. A 12mm plate was used for fixation.  
* Closure: Hemostasis and irrigation were performed. A H-vac suction device was inserted. The wound was closed in anatomical layers with sutures.  
Patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
> **Description:**  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone without skeletal fixation. Aseptic draping was performed.  
2. The C-arm was used to confirm the C3 to C6 levels, and a midline linear skin incision was made for muscle dissection. A self-retaining retractor was applied to adequately expose the laminae of C3–C6.  
3. Bilateral laminae were drilled. On the left side, the dural sac was identified, and the laminae were completely separated. The laminae were then pushed from left to right to achieve decompression posterior to the dural sac. A Medtronic Centerpiece plate (10mm × 1 piece, 12mm × 3 pieces) was placed and secured with screws to perform an open-door laminoplasty.  
4. During the procedure, motor evoked potentials (MEP) and somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) in both upper extremities were weak, with no observed changes on intraoperative monitoring (IOM) pre- and post-surgery.  
5. After meticulous bleeding control, saline irrigation was performed, and two Hemovac drains were inserted. The wound was closed layer by layer.  
6. The patient was transferred to the recovery room post-surgery.

Intraoperative Notable Events:  
1. After general anesthesia, the patient was positioned prone with slight neck flexion and head pinning using the Mayfield head fixator. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was set up. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. The level was confirmed using a C-arm. A midline skin incision was made spanning the C2-C7 spinous process level, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose the C3-7 lamina to the boundary of the lateral masses.  
3. A trough was created with a drill at the boundary between the left C3-6 lamina and lateral mass. The lamina and lateral mass boundary was cut using a drill and punch. The ligamentum flavum was removed, and the dural sac was identified. The upper half of both C7 laminae was drilled, exposing and removing the ligamentum flavum to achieve adequate decompression of the dural sac. A blunt hook was used to confirm the connection between the two sides.  
4. The posterior arch was retracted and fixed with four titanium plates (Medtronic, medical device manufacturer) to complete the open door laminoplasty at C3-6.  
   - Centerpiece OD plate Medtronic 12mm × 4  
   - Centerpiece 2.6 Screw Medtronic 2.6×5mm × 9  
5. Irrigation was performed, and one HVAC device was inserted. The wound was closed layer by layer. No IOM changes occurred during surgery.  
6. After extubation, the patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU).
