2. C-arm imaging was used to confirm the cervical spine level. A linear skin incision was made along the right side skin crease to expose the C3-4 vertebral bodies. Soft tissue dissection was performed, including incision of the platysma muscle and dissection of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and carotid sheath, with lateral retraction. The right superior thyroid artery was ligated. The fascia and longus colli muscle were dissected to expose the C3-4 vertebral bodies, with a Casper retractor used to maintain surgical space.  
3. The C3-4 intervertebral disc was identified and removed using a currette and pituitary forceps. A left-sided posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) defect and herniated disc were noted. The PLL was removed to confirm complete decompression of the thecal sac and restoration of cord pulsation. A PEEK cage filled with allograft bone was inserted into the C3-4 intervertebral disc space.  
4. Hemostasis and irrigation were performed, followed by placement of a single J-P drain. The wound was closed in layers and the procedure concluded.

**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Syringomyelia

**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] 1:34 PM  
**Surgery End Time:** [DATE] 4:55 PM  
**Intraoperative Findings:**  
**Description:**  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in a prone position with head fixation. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied, and aseptic draping was performed.  
2. A C-arm was used to confirm the spinal level, and a linear skin incision was made to adequately expose the C6-7 lamina. Paraspinal muscles were split to expose the lamina, followed by a burr and punch to perform a C6-7, 2-level laminectomy, exposing the dura. The dura was not tense.  
3. A linear incision was made on the dura, revealing the arachnoid membrane. Upon incising the arachnoid membrane, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) gushed out at a relatively high pressure. The dura and arachnoid membrane were sutured together and reflected laterally to expose the spinal cord.  
4. A postspinal vein was noted along the midline of the spinal cord, making myelotomy difficult. To avoid vein damage, a cottonoid was used to cover the cord, exposing only the area free of the vein for myelotomy. A midline myelotomy was performed, allowing visualization of the syrinx’s internal space. A blunt hook was used to confirm the potential space within the syrinx, verifying cyst fenestration. Primary dura closure was then performed.  
5. Bipolar coagulation was used for meticulous hemostasis. A saw was used to partially remove the spinous processes of C6 and C7, followed by a miniplate to perform laminoplasty. The wound was closed layer-by-layer, and the surgery was concluded. Intraoperative monitoring showed no changes.  
**Patient was transferred to the recovery room.**  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Time of Documentation:** [DATE] 7:19 AM"

Intraoperative Notes:  
1. General anesthesia was administered with the patient in a supine position and neck extended. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was set up. Aseptic draping was performed.  
2. The level was confirmed using a C-arm, and a transverse incision was made along the skin line at the C3-4 level on the right side. The platysma muscle was incised, followed by dissection along the medial border of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. The carotid sheath was retracted to the right side, while the esophagus and trachea were retracted to the left side. The longus coli muscle was coagulated, and a retractor was placed to visualize the C3-4 and C4-5 levels. The C3-4 disc level was confirmed, and Caspar screws were inserted into the C3, C4, and C5 vertebral bodies followed by distraction.  
3. A discectomy was performed at the C3-4 level, with the disc removed using a punch, curette, and pituitary forceps. The posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was identified and removed. Although the dura was not directly observed, a thin layer remained, confirming adequate decompression.  
4. The cage was filled with allograft bone chips and a 14 x 14 x 7mm Anyplus GS medical cage was inserted at the C3-4 level.  
5. The same procedure was repeated at the C4-5 level using a 14 x 14 x 7mm cage.  
6. Meticulous hemostasis and copious saline irrigation were performed. A Jackson-Pratt drain was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers. Surgery was concluded.  
Intraoperative IOM showed no abnormalities.

**Description:**  
1. The patient was placed in a supine position with neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied. Betadine soaping and painting were performed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. After confirming the level with a C-arm, a collar incision was made on the left side at the C4-5 level along the Langer line. The platysma muscle was incised, and dissection was performed along the medial border of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. The carotid sheath was retracted laterally, while the esophagus and trachea were retracted medially. The longus coli muscle was coagulated, and a retractor was placed to fully visualize the C4-5 level. A Caspar screw was inserted into C4-5, and the level was confirmed again with a C-arm before distraction.  
3. Using a punch, curette, and pituitary forceps, the C4-5 disc material was removed, and the posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was identified. During PLL removal, the dural sac was visualized, confirming adequate decompression.  
4. Cancellous bone chips were packed into the cage, and a GS Medical Cage (14mm x 6mm) was inserted into the C4-5 disc space.  
5. Meticulous bleeding control and copious saline irrigation were performed. A JP drain was placed, and the wound was closed in layers.  
**Intraoperative IOM findings:** No abnormalities noted. The patient regained consciousness from anesthesia and was transferred to the PACU.

**Surgical End Time:** [DATE] 1:16:00 PM  
**Intraoperative Findings and Procedures:**  
1. The patient was placed in the supine position with neutral alignment, followed by neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied, and the surgical site was prepared with betadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping.  
2. A cervical spine level check was performed using a C-arm guide. A right-sided transverse skin incision was made along the skin crease to expose the C6-7 intervertebral disc.  
3. Soft tissue dissection was performed to expose the platysma muscle, followed by a longitudinal incision. The sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle and carotid sheath were identified. Dissection was carried along the medial border of the SCM, with the carotid sheath retracted laterally and the esophagus/trachea retracted medially.  
4. Dissection of the fascia and longus colli muscle was performed to expose the C6-7 vertebral body. A Casper screw was inserted along the midline. A Casper retractor was used to distract the C6-7 intervertebral space. Disc material was removed using a fifteen blade, pituitary forceps, and punch. Under microscopic visualization, the disc material and posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) were thoroughly removed. The thecal sac was confirmed to be adequately decompressed.  
5. An allograft bone cage was inserted into the C6-7 intervertebral space. Meticulous hemostasis and copious saline irrigation were performed. A Jackson (JP) drain was placed, and the wound was closed in layers. No intraoperative IOM abnormalities were noted. The patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU) after regaining consciousness from anesthesia.  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Time:** [DATE] 13:58"

**Description:**  
1. The patient was placed in the supine position under general anesthesia, and neck extension was performed. Bethadine soaping and painting were conducted, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. Using C-arm fluoroscopy, the C3-4 level was confirmed, and an oblique skin incision was made along the medial border of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle.  
3. Soft tissue dissection was performed to expose the platysma muscle, followed by a longitudinal incision. The SCM and carotid sheath were identified. Dissection was carried along the medial border of the SCM, with two veins ligated using vascular clips and surgical ties. The carotid sheath was retracted laterally, and the esophagus and trachea were retracted medially.  
4. Dissection of the fascia and longus colli muscle exposed the C3-4 vertebral bodies (VB). A Casper screw was inserted along the midline. Due to severe osteoporosis, the screw was inserted without drilling. A Casper retractor was used to distract the C3-4 intervertebral space. Disc material was removed using a #15 blade, pituitary forceps, and punch. Under microscopic visualization, disc material was removed, and the intact posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was confirmed. To achieve decompression, the PLL was removed to expose the spinal cord. The thecal sac was confirmed to be adequately exposed.  
5. Bleeding was controlled meticulously using floseal. A MC Plus Cage with a Genesis Sponge (10×10×20 mm) was inserted into the C5-6 intervertebral space. Due to severe osteoporosis, an Atlantis Plate was used to stabilize the Cage at the C3 and C4 VBs.  
6. Copious saline irrigation was performed. A JP drain was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers. The patient was transferred to the PACU after regaining consciousness.

Intraoperative Notable Findings:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient's head was elevated using a head rest, and the patient was placed in a supine position with slight neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied.  
2. Using a C-arm guide, the C4-5 intervertebral space level was confirmed. A paramedian transverse skin incision was planned and marked, followed by betadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping.  
3. A skin incision was performed along the skin crease on the left paramedian transverse plane. Subcutaneous tissue dissection was performed to expose the platysma muscle, which was then transversely dissected to expose the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Dissection was performed between the sternocleidomastoid muscle's medial border and the infrahyoid muscle to expose the carotid sheath, esophagus, and trachea.  
4. The carotid sheath was tractioned laterally, and the esophagus and trachea were tractioned medially to confirm the C4-5 vertebral body and intervertebral disc. All and bilateral longus coli muscles were coagulated to create space, and CASPER screws were inserted into the C4 and C5 vertebral bodies under C-arm guidance. A CCR retractor and CASPER retractor were then applied.  
5. The C4-5 intervertebral disc was incised using a #15 blade, and the disc material was removed using pituitary forceps and a curette. The posterior uncinate process was flattened using a high-speed drill. The posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was exposed, but due to its firmness, thickness, and calcification, only the anterior portion was removed via drilling. The remaining PLL was removed using a hook and punch to expose the dura mater. The dura mater, which had been displaced posteriorly, decompressed and shifted anteriorly upon removal of the PLL.  
6. A MC+ cage (14x14xH6, GS Medical) with a genesis sponge (Hanmi) packing was inserted into the C4-5 intervertebral space under C-arm guidance. The CASPER retractor, CCR retractor, and CASPER screws were sequentially removed.  
7. After bleeding control, a Jackson-Pratt (J-P) drain was inserted. The omohyoid muscle was sutured, and the wound was closed in a layer-by-layer fashion.  
No significant changes in Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) were observed during the procedure. The patient was transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit following surgery.

**Surgery Date:** [DATE]

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
1. The patient was placed in supine position under general anesthesia. The head was elevated using a head rest, and the neck was slightly extended for stabilization. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied, followed by a C-arm guide level check. Betadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping were performed.  
2. A paramedian transverse skin incision was made at the right C5-6 level. After a transverse incision of the platysma muscle, dissection was performed along the medial border of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle to access the area. The trachea and esophagus were retracted medially, and the carotid sheath was retracted laterally to identify the C5-6 vertebral body and intervertebral space. The operative field was covered by omohyoid muscle, which was tied and cut. CCR retractor, Casper screw, and distractor were sequentially applied.  
3. The C5-6 intervertebral space was distracted, and bony spurs on the anterior side were drilled and removed. A #15 blade was used to incise the disc material, which was then removed using a pituitary, curette, and punch. The disc material was calcified and yellowish in color.  
4. After complete removal of the disc material, the posterior rim of the C5-6 vertebral body was removed to expose the posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL). A rupture of the PLL was observed in the central portion, with calcified disc material extruding into the thecal sac and strong adhesion to the thecal sac. The PLL was thoroughly removed using a punch and pituitary, and as much disc material as possible was removed. However, extruded disc material in the superior, inferior, and lateral regions remained due to severe adhesion to the thecal sac, which posed a risk of cord injury. Decompression of the neural structures was confirmed. Hemostasis was achieved using Floseal.  
5. A cancellous sponge block (Hanmi Medical, 10×10×20 mm) was placed in the C5-6 intervertebral space with a cervical MC+ cage (GS Medical, 14×14×6 mm). The anterior bony spur was further drilled, and anterior fixation was performed using a plate (Atlantis Plate, Medtronics, 27.5 mm) and screws (Atlantis Screw, Medtronics, 12 mm × 1, 13 mm × 2, 14 mm × 1).  
6. The CCR retractor, Casper screw, and distractor were removed, and hemostasis was achieved using Surgicel. A JP drain was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers. (The omohyoid muscle was reconstructed.)  
**Intraoperative Electrophysiological (EP) Changes:** None observed.  
**Postoperative Course:** The patient was transferred to the recovery room.

4. A JP drain (1 unit) was inserted. The wound was closed in layers, and the surgery was concluded (skin closure with steri-strips).  
5. Post-extubation, the patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU).

**Date:** [DATE]  
**Author:** [NAME]  
**Procedure Name:** Anterior fusion, C-spine; Posterior fixation; Decompressive laminectomy  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical myelopathy; Herniated disc disease of cervical spine with radiculopathy; Spondylosis with radiculopathy  
**Anesthesia Type:** General  
**Surgery Date:** [DATE]  
**Surgeon:** [NAME]  
**Assistant:** [NAME]  
**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] 12:28:00  
**Surgery End Time:** [DATE] 18:32:00  
**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
**Anterior Approach - C4-5 Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion (ACDF):**  
1. The patient was placed in supine position with a headrest and neck elevator to achieve neck extension. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, and antiseptic draping was performed.  
2. After confirming the C4-5 level with a C-arm guide, a left paramedian transverse skin incision was made along the skin crease. Subcutaneous dissection exposed the platysma muscle, which was dissected transversely to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. Dissection between the SCM medial border and infrahyoid muscle revealed the carotid sheath, esophagus, and trachea, which were retracted laterally and medially to visualize the C4-5 vertebral bodies (VB) and intervertebral disc. The longus coli muscles were coagulated to create space for retractors, and CASPER screws were inserted into the C4 and C5 VBs, confirmed with a C-arm.  
3. A CCR retractor was placed on the longus coli muscles, and the intervertebral space was widened using a distractor. After incising the C4-5 disc, discectomy was performed with a punch and curette, and endplate preparation was completed. Both Luschka’s joints were confirmed. Disc material was thoroughly removed using a pituitary and punch, and the endplate was exposed with a curette. Hypertrophic ligamentum flavum (PLL) was removed from the outer layer using a punch, while the inner layer was left intact except for a small portion near the median. The dural sac was partially exposed medially.  
4. A cage filled with Osteogrow (bone graft material) was inserted into the C4-5 disc space. The CASPER screws and CCR retractor were removed.  
**Osteogrow (bone graft material), Hans (implant), 5cc, 1ea; MC + Cage, MC Plus, 14x14x7mm, 1ea**  
5. After hemostasis, a JP drain was inserted into the neck wound, and the wound was closed in layers.  
**Posterior Approach - C4-5-6 Laminectomy (+C7 Undercutting) and Posterior Fixation via Lateral Mass Screws:**  
6. The patient was repositioned to prone, and neck flexion was performed for skeletal fixation. Post-fixation measurements showed symmetric thenar motor evoked potential (MEP) reduction of 10–20%. A C-arm confirmed the cage was shifted anteriorly by several millimeters compared to the supine position imaging.  
7. After completing the posterior approach, the anterior exploration and cage repositioning were planned. The C2 and C7 vertebrae were palpated, and the C4-6 level was reconfirmed with a C-arm. A midline skin incision was made to cover C3-C7, and the trapezius, splenius capitis, and semispinalis muscles were split to expose the spinous tips.  
8. The lamina muscles were dissected subperiosteally, and the multifidus muscles were dissected to expose the C4-6 laminae and the upper lamina of C7.  
9. Lateral mass screws were inserted bilaterally at C4-5-6.  
**Poseidon Cervical Posterior Screw, Innotec, 3.5x14mm, 6ea**  
10. Under microscopic view, laminectomy was performed at C4-5-6, and the ligamentum flavum was completely removed to confirm decompression of the thecal sac. The C7 vertebra was undercut using a 4mm cutting burr and punch.  
11. The rod was bent appropriately and fixed with capping. Finalization was performed, with a crosslink placed between C4 and C5 for fixation. After HVAC insertion, the wound was closed in layers.  
**Crosslink, Innotec, CLP25A, 25mm**  
**Anterior Approach - Cage Repositioning and Plating:**  
12. To prevent additional anterior malposition of the cage, anterior plating was planned. The patient was repositioned supine, and the previous ACDF incision was reopened, with all muscle sutures removed to expose the disc space and cage.  
13. The cage was found to be grossly anteriorly malpositioned, protruding 2mm ventral to the VB anterior margin. Using an impactor, it was carefully repositioned 1mm dorsal to the VB anterior margin. An ATLANTIS plate was used for C4-5 anterior plating.  
**ATLANTIS Plate, 25mm, 1ea; ATLANTIS Screw, 14mm variable, 4ea**  
14. The previous JP drain was removed, and a new JP drain was inserted. The wound was closed in layers.  
By the time the posterior approach was completed, bilateral thenar MEPs had recovered to the preoperative level, with no significant changes noted on IOM. The patient was extubated and transferred to PACU.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 14:53"
}

**Procedure:** Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion (ACDF)  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical Myelopathy  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Cervical Myelopathy, Herniated Disc Disease of Cervical Spine with Radiculopathy  
**Anesthesia Type:** General  
**Surgery Date:** [DATE]  
**Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] at 10:40 AM  
**Surgery End Time:** [DATE] at 12:09 PM  
**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned supine with a headrest and neck elevator to achieve neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was installed, and antiseptics and aseptic draping were performed.  
2. After confirming the C5-6 level using a C-arm guide, a left paramedian transverse skin incision was made along the skin crease. Subcutaneous dissection was performed to expose the platysma muscle, which was then dissected transversely to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. The space between the SCM muscle and infrahyoid muscle was dissected to expose the carotid sheath, esophagus, and trachea. These structures were retracted laterally and medially to identify the C5-6 vertebral bodies (VB) and intervertebral disc. The longus coli muscles were coagulated, and retractors were placed to secure the surgical field. CASPER screws were inserted into the C5 and C6 VB, and their position was verified using a C-arm.  
3. A CCR retractor was placed on the longus coli muscles, and retraction was performed bilaterally and fixed. CASPER screws were distracted using a distractor to widen the intervertebral space. After incising the C5-6 disc, discectomy was performed using a punch and curette, and endplate preparation was completed. Both Luschka's joints were confirmed. Disc material was thoroughly removed using a punch and pituitary, and the endplate was exposed using a curette. Tissues resembling a disc on MRI, which were compressing the spinal canal, were identified as bony spurs and removed using a punch and drill.  
4. A cage filled with Osteogrow (bone graft material) was inserted into the C5-6 disc space. The CASPER screw distractor and CCR retractor were removed.  
**Materials Used:**  
- Osteogrow (bone graft material), Hans (bone graft material), 5cc, 1ea  
- MC + cage, MC Plus, 14x14x6mm, 1ea  
5. After bleeding control, a JP drain was inserted into the neck wound, and the wound was closed in a layer-by-layer fashion.  
**Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM):** No significant changes were noted.  
**Postoperative:** The patient was extubated and transferred to the PACU.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Timestamp:** [DATE] at 7:57 PM"
}

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
> **Description**  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia. Skeletal fixation was performed, followed by intraoperative electroencephalographic (EP) monitoring. Bethadine soaping, painting, and aseptic draping were applied.  
2. A midline skin incision was made from C3 to C5. Dissection was performed along the nuchal ligament. The C3-C5 spinous processes and laminae were identified, and subperiosteal dissection was performed to fully expose the lateral masses of C3-C5.  
3. The entry point was positioned 1 mm medial to the midline of the lateral mass. A 2 mm cutting burr was used to create the entry point into the cortical bone. Under fluoroscopic guidance, the superior inclination was aligned parallel to the lateral axis of the lateral mass, and the medio-lateral inclination was set at approximately 30 degrees. The cutting burr was positioned to advance halfway into the lateral mass.  
4. A screw guide was used to advance 15 mm, creating a hole for the screw. A 3.5 mm x 16 mm screw was then inserted.  
5. The same method was applied for lateral mass screw insertion at C3, C4, and C5.  
6. The screws were connected using a rod.  
**Rod:** 30 mm, 2 pieces  
**Screw:** 3.5 mm x 16 mm, 6 pieces  
7. A Hemovac drain (1 piece) was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers.  
8. No significant changes in intraoperative monitoring (IOM) were observed during the procedure. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit without extubation.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 7:26 PM"

**Neurosurgery** ([DATE])  
**Procedure:** Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion (ACDF)  
**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Herniated disc disease of the cervical spine  
**Postoperative Diagnosis:** Herniated disc disease of the cervical spine with radiculopathy  
**Anesthesia Type:** General Anesthesia  
**Surgical Date:** [DATE]  
**Primary Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Assistant Surgeon 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] 9:14 AM  
**Surgery End Time:** [DATE] 10:35 AM  
**Intraoperative Notes:**  
**Description:**  
1. The patient was positioned supine with the headrest elevated and neck extended using a neck elevator. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, and antiseptic preparation and aseptic draping were performed.  
2. Using a C-arm guide, the C5-6 level was confirmed. A skin incision was made along the left side skin crease. Subcutaneous dissection was performed to expose the platysma muscle, which was then dissected transversely to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. The omohyoid muscle was dissected to retract medially, and the SCM muscle's medial border and infrahyoid muscle space were dissected to expose the carotid sheath, esophagus, and trachea. These structures were retracted laterally and medially to identify the C5-6 vertebral bodies (VB) and intervertebral disc. The longus capitis and longus coli muscles were coagulated to create space for retractors, and Caspar screws were inserted into the C5 and C6 VBs. The level was verified using a C-arm. A Casspar cervical retractor was placed on the longus coli muscles, and the retractor space was expanded using a distractor.  
3. After an incision was made into the C5-6 disc, a disectomy was performed using a punch and curette, followed by endplate preparation. Both Luschka's joints were confirmed. The disc material was thoroughly removed using a punch and pituitary, and the endplate was exposed using a curette.  
4. A disc compressing the spinal cord on the right side was removed based on MRI findings. The posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) remained intact. The outer layer of the PLL was removed using a punch, while the inner layer was left intact to avoid exposing the dural sac.  
5. A cage (MC+C-cage, 14 X 14 X H6, SpineArt) filled with Surechip (5cc, Hans BioMedical) was inserted into the C5-6 disc space. The position was confirmed using a C-arm. The Caspar screw distractor and Casspar cervical retractor were removed.  
6. Hemostasis was achieved, and a JP 1ea drain was inserted. Layer-by-layer closure was performed.  
7. No significant changes were noted during IOM. The patient was extubated and transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU).  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Time of Completion:** [DATE] [TIME]"

Intraoperative Findings:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in supine position with neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was installed, and antiseptics and aseptic draping were performed. Baseline findings included weak MEP in the left deltoid and reduced SEP (70-80%) in both lower extremities.  
2. Using a C-arm guide, the C6-7 level was confirmed. A diagonal skin incision was made along the medial margin of the right sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. Subcutaneous dissection exposed the platysma muscle and SCM. The SCM and omohyoid muscle were retracted laterally to create space, and the carotid sheath on the lateral side was identified. Progressing medially, the prevertebral space was opened. C6 and C7 vertebral bodies (VB) and intervertebral discs were visualized, and confirmation was repeated using the C-arm. The longus capitis and longus coli muscles were coagulated and dissected to secure the retractor space. A Caspar cervical retractor was placed on the longus coli muscles and fixed laterally.  
3. Caspar screws were inserted into the C6 and C7 VBs, and a distractor was used to widen the intervertebral space. During disc removal, a ruptured disc fragment posterior to the posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was identified and removed, revealing a defect in the PLL. Remaining disc material was thoroughly excised using pituitary forceps and punches, and cord decompression was confirmed.  
4. Both endplates were exposed via curettage. A tri-cortical bone block (0.9*2.5 cm) was placed in the C6/7 discectomy space. Using the C-arm, the disc space was confirmed to be distracted compared to preoperative imaging. Anterior cervical plating and screw instrumentation were performed, and the position was verified with the C-arm.  
   - Skyline Anterior Cervical System, Plate, 20mm, DePuy Synthes, 1 piece  
   - Skyline Anterior Cervical System, Screw, 14mm, DePuy Synthes, 4 pieces  
5. Hemostasis was achieved using Floseal and bipolar coagulation. A JP drain (1 piece) was inserted, and the wound was closed layer by layer. The skin was closed with steri-strips. No intraoperative IOM changes occurred, and the patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.

**Preoperative Diagnosis:** Spinal Cord Compression, Cervical

**Anesthesia Type:** General Anesthesia

**Surgical End Time:** [DATE] at 2:25 PM  
**Intraoperative Findings:** No surgical findings > Intraoperative imaging & postoperative X-ray  
**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. Under general anesthesia, patient was placed in supine position with neck extension on the horseshoe. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
2. Left-sided approach was used. After confirming the C5-6 level with a C-arm X-ray machine, a skin crease-following incision was made to expose the C5-6 vertebral bodies (VB). Platysma muscle was incised, and dissection was performed to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. Dissection along the medial border of the SCM muscle was performed to retract the carotid sheath laterally. The esophagus and trachea were retracted medially. A retractor was placed to confirm the C5-6 VB and intervertebral disc. All and bilateral longus coli muscles were coagulated. After confirming the level with a C-arm X-ray machine, a Casper screw was inserted into the C5-6 VB.  
3. C5-6 discectomy was performed. After annulotomy, discectomy was carried out using a punch and pituitary forceps. During microscopic visualization, drilling was performed with a curette to prepare the end plate. The posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was removed to expose the ventral portion of the dural sac.  
4. A test cage was inserted into the disc space to confirm the size. An appropriately sized cage (MC+ Cage (H6mm*14mm*14mm)) filled with bone chips was then placed into the disc space under C-arm guidance.  
5. Saline irrigation was performed. Active bleeding was confirmed to be absent. A JP drain was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers. The skin was closed with steri-strips.  
6. Extubation was performed, and the patient was transferred to the PACU via a T-cannula.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]

Anesthesia Type: General Anesthesia

Surgery End Time: [DATE] at 11:38 AM  
Intraoperative Notable Events: No intraoperative complications. Intraoperative photographs taken.  
Surgical Technique and Procedure: ACDF at C4-6, Right Approach  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in a supine position with neck extension. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed as usual.  
Right-side approach was initiated. Using a C-arm, the C4-6 level was confirmed, and an oblique skin incision was made over the vertebral body (VB) at the C4-6 level. The skin incision was followed by dissection of the platysma muscle and sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle, with the carotid sheath identified. The SCM muscle was retracted laterally along with the sheath, while the esophagus and trachea were retracted medially. A retractor was placed to visualize the C4-6 VB and intervertebral disc. The medial borders of the longus coli muscles were coagulated with a bovie device. Casper screws were inserted into the VBs at C4, C5, and C6 levels, confirmed with a C-arm.  
C4-5 discectomy was performed. After annulotomy, discectomy was carried out using a punch and pituitary forceps, with end plate preparation using a curette. Both uncinate processes were identified, and the disc was removed laterally to the margin. A defect was noted on the ventral side of the PLL, suggesting disc rupture. The PLL was peeled to identify the inner layer, which was intact. The entire PLL was transversely removed to expose the dural sac, with disc material between the PLLs removed. A dural indentation was observed on the left side. The C5 upper margin was drilled, and a sharp hook was used to remove the inferiorly migrated disc fragment.  
The same approach was applied for C5-6. In this case, diffuse disc protrusion was the main issue, and the PLL was intact, so removal was not performed.  
After disc space distraction, a cage filled with demineralized bone matrix (DBM) and allograft bone chip was inserted. Alignment was confirmed using a C-arm, and the construct was fixed with a plate.  
Saline irrigation was performed, and no active bleeding was noted. A JP drain was inserted, and the wound was closed layer by layer, with the skin closed using steri-strips.  
Post-extubation, the patient was transferred to the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU). No changes in intraoperative monitoring (IOM) were observed pre- and post-surgery.  
Instruments Used: Athena C-plate 47MM 1 ea, Athena screw 4.0*12MM 6 ea, C7 c-cage12*14*H5 1 ea (C4-5), C7 c-cage12*14*H6 1 ea (C5-6), Cancellous Chip [BRAND] 5cc, Medy Fuse (DBM) 3cc  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: [DATE] at 11:53 AM"

Skin incision, dissection of platysma muscle and sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle to identify carotid sheath. SCM muscle retracted laterally with sheath. Blood vessels were abundant; hemoclip used. Both uncinate processes identified, and disc lateral margin thoroughly removed. Ventral side showed ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament (OPLL). Attempted removal with punch and hook but found difficult. C4 VB inferior portion cut with cutting burr, then diamond burr used to remove as thin as possible. 1mm punch used to gradually extract OPLL, exposing the dural sac.  
    - Disc space distraction performed; cage filled with DBM and allograft bone chips inserted. Alignment confirmed with C-arm, then plate fixation applied.     - Extubation performed; transferred to PACU. No IOM changes noted pre- and post-surgery.

Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned supine with neck extension. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed. Using a C-arm fluoroscope, the C4-5 level was confirmed. A transverse skin incision was made along the right anterior cervical skin crease. Subcutaneous dissection was performed to expose the platysma muscle, which was then transversely dissected to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. The space between the SCM muscle and infrahyoid muscle was dissected to expose the carotid sheath, esophagus, and trachea. These structures were retracted laterally and medially to identify the C4 and C5 vertebral bodies (VB) and intervertebral disc. The C-arm fluoroscope was used to confirm these findings.  
The longus capitis (ALL) and longus coli medial borders were dissected to establish retractor space. A CCR retractor was placed over the longus coli muscles and fixed laterally and medially. Caspar screws were inserted into the C4 and C5 VBs. The Caspar screws were distracted using a distractor to widen the intervertebral space. The C4-5 disc was incised, and disc material was removed using pituitary forceps and a punch. The posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was identified and removed to expose the dural sac. Decompression of the dural sac was confirmed.  
A cage (Innotech, 12 x 14 x 7mm) filled with Surefuse (1 cc, HANSCARE) was placed into the discectomy space. The C-arm fluoroscope confirmed that the disc space was distracted compared to preoperative imaging.  
After hemostasis, a JP 1ea drain was inserted, and the wound was closed layer by layer. The skin was closed with steri-strips. No intraoperative IOM changes were noted. The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.

Surgical Record (DATE)  
Surgical Procedure: ACDF (Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion)  
Preoperative Diagnosis: Cervical Myelopathy  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Herniated Disc Disease of the Cervical Spine  
Anesthesia Type: General  
Surgical Date: [DATE]  
Primary Surgeon: [NAME]  
Assistant Surgeons: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Surgical Start Time: [DATE] 8:59:00 AM  
Surgical End Time: [DATE] 10:28:00 AM  
Intraoperative Notable Findings:  
- No significant findings during the procedure.  
- ACDF at C5-6 (Right Approach) performed.  
Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
Under general anesthesia with the patient in supine position and neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed. Using a C-arm guide, the C5-6 level was confirmed. A transverse skin incision was made along the right anterior neck skin crease. Subcutaneous dissection was performed to expose the platysma muscle, which was then dissected transversely to expose the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. The space between the SCM muscle and infrahyoid muscle was dissected to expose the carotid sheath, esophagus, and trachea, which were retracted laterally and medially to identify the C5 and C6 vertebral bodies (VB) and intervertebral disc. The C-arm was used to confirm the anatomical landmarks. The longus coli medial borders were dissected to prepare the retractor space, and a CCR retractor was placed on the longus coli muscles for lateral and medial retraction, then secured. Caspar screws were inserted into the C5 and C6 VBs. The Caspar screws were distracted using a distractor to widen the intervertebral space. After a disc incision at C5-6, the disc material was removed using pituitary forceps and a punch. The posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was identified and removed to expose the dural sac, which was confirmed to be adequately decompressed. A cancellous chip (5cc, Hansbio) was placed into a cage (brand cage, 12 x 14 x 5mm) and positioned in the discectomy space. The C-arm was used to confirm that the disc space was distracted compared to preoperative imaging. Hemostasis was achieved, followed by the insertion of a JP 1ea drain. The wound was closed in layers, and the procedure was completed. Steri-strips were applied to the skin. No intraoperative IOM changes were observed. The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  

Instrumentation:  
- Cage: Brand Cage, 12 x 14 x 5mm  
- Bone Graft: Demineralized Bone Matrix (DBM), Cancellous Chip (5cc, Hansbio)  

Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: [DATE] 10:42 AM"

Intraoperative Notes:  
> Open door cervical laminoplasty performed at C3-C6. Right-sided open approach and epidural hematoma identified, right-side removal executed.  
Procedure and Technique:  
1. General anesthesia administered; patient positioned supine with head fixation and 0° rotation. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) applied, aseptic draping completed.  
2. C-arm used to confirm C3-C7 positioning. Midline skin incision performed, C3-6 spinous processes exposed. Periosteal dissection conducted laterally to expose laminae. C-arm reconfirmed C5 spinous process positioning.  
3. Rongeur utilized to remove C3-6 spinous processes. Drill and punch instruments used to partially remove laminae at the left side (C4-6) to create a gutter. Right-side C4-6 laminectomy performed to establish a hinge, with laminae elevated. Ligamentum flavum within the laminae was removed using a punch. Epidural hematoma identified beneath the elevated laminae, firmly adherent to the dura. Detachment achieved via sharp hook, followed by removal. No dural injury noted. Laminoplasty plate secured to the right laminae; IOM showed no abnormalities during surgery.  
4. Two hemovac drains (HV) inserted. Wound closed in layers, and surgery concluded. Patient awakened and transferred to recovery.  
Instruments Used: CAPAX Open Door Plate (4 units), 2.4 mm screws (5 mm, 15 units)  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Date Written: [DATE] at 7:33 AM"
}

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
- **Surgical Findings:** No significant intraoperative changes were noted.  
- **Procedure:**  
  1. The patient was placed in the prone position with head fixation using a Mayfield frame. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was established, followed by aseptic draping.  
  2. A midline, vertical skin incision was made to include the C3-C7 levels. The muscular dissection and detachment were performed to expose the bilateral laminae and spinous processes.  
  3. A high-speed drill was used to perform lamina drilling at C3-C6, creating a hinge site on the left and a gutter on the right. The C7 spinous process was drilled and removed using a punch to achieve an upper laminectomy at C7. The gutter side was opened using a dissector and punch to expose the dura. A center piece plate and screws were planned for fixation, but due to size mismatch and hinge fracture, a laminectomy was performed.  
  4. Antibiotic mixed irrigation was administered, and a single closed drain was inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was performed, and the surgery was completed.  
**Postoperative Course:** The patient was transferred to the recovery room post-surgery.  

**Final Notes:**  
- All procedures were performed without complications.  
- No additional intraoperative interventions were required.  
- The patient’s condition remains stable.

Intraoperative Notable Findings: No significant intraoperative monitoring (IOM) changes.  
Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. The patient was placed in prone position with head fixation using a Mayfield frame. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline, vertical skin incision was performed to include the C3-C7 level. The muscle was dissected and detached, and subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose both laminae and the spinous process.  
3. A high-speed drill was used to perform lamina drilling at C4-C6. The left side was prepared as a hinge site, while the right side was created as a gutter. Using a dissector and punch, the gutter side was opened to expose the dura. An open door laminoplasty was performed using a laminoplasty plate and screws for fixation.  
4. A drill was used to drill the spinous process and part of the lamina at C7. Bone adherent to the dura was removed using a punch to perform an upper laminectomy at C7, completing the dural decompression.  
5. Antibiotic mixed irrigation was administered, and a hemovac drain was inserted. The wound was closed in layers, and the surgery was concluded.  
Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the recovery room.  
Instruments Used: Capax OD plate, 3 pieces  
Author: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Completion Time: [DATE] 16:19"
}

Intraoperative Notes:  
> No significant intraoperative monitoring changes.  
> Open door laminoplasty performed at C5-C6, right side open.  
Procedure and Technique:  
1. The patient was placed in prone position under general anesthesia with head fixation using a Mayfield frame. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was initiated, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline, vertical skin incision was made to include the C5-C6 level. Dissection and detachment of the muscular layers exposed the bilateral laminae and spinous process.  
3. High-speed drilling was performed at the C5-C6 laminae to create a hinge site on the left and a gutter on the right. Using a dissector and punch, the gutter side was opened to expose the dura. A center piece plate and screws were utilized for fixation. Dural bulging was noted at the laminoplasty site, indicating significant cord compression. No dural injury or hinge fracture was observed.  
4. Antibiotic mixed irrigation was performed, and a single closed drain was inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was completed, and the procedure was concluded. The patient was transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit.

Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in a prone position with neck flexion, Mayfield head fixation, reverse Trendelenburg position, and antiseptic aseptic draping was performed.  
2. After palpation of C2 and C7, a midline skin incision was made at the midpoints of the spinous processes for C2-3-4-5. The nuchal ligament was followed to identify the spinous process (bifida), and subperiosteal dissection was performed bilaterally to expose both laminae and lateral masses. (Severe facet joint arthropathy was observed in the bilateral lateral masses of C3-4-5, with bony spurs covering the facet joints.)  
3. A 3mm drill was used to remove the outer cortex and cancellous bone at the boundary between the left lamina and lateral mass of C3-4-5, leaving only the inner table to form a hinge.  
4. A gutter was created on the right side using the same method as the left, and the remaining inner table bone was removed with a punch to expose the dura, creating an opening site. The lamina was then gently elevated to maintain an elevated position, with observation of spinal cord swelling in the dorsal space.  
5. A center piece plate and screw (GS Medical product) were used to achieve fixation, performing a right open-door laminoplasty.  
6. Massive irrigation was performed using antibiotics mixed saline, and a hemovac (m) drain was inserted. Layer-by-layer wound closure was performed, and the surgery was concluded.  
Postoperative: The patient was transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit. No significant intraoperative monitoring changes were observed. (The patient had an intraoperative monitoring amplitude of approximately 80 on the left upper extremity at the start of surgery, which remained similar postoperatively. Other regions maintained values above 120 pre- and post-surgery.)

**Assistant 1:** [NAME]  
**Surgery Start Time:** [DATE] 3:15:00 PM

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
- Cervical spine findings: C5, C6 left open, left C6-7 foraminotomy. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) showed no change. Massive epidural venous bleeding noted.  
**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was placed in a prone position with neck flexion, Mayfield head fixation, antiseptic preparation, and aseptic draping performed. IOM setup completed.  
2. Using a C-arm, the level was confirmed, and a midline skin incision was made to expose the C5-6-7 spinous processes. The incision followed the avascular plane of the nuchal ligament. Bleeding was noted during muscle dissection.  
3. Lateral masses were exposed bilaterally. For C5 and C6, the right laminae were drilled, leaving cortical bone and creating a gutter. The left laminae were drilled near the V point, thinning them to an eggshell-like structure, and then opened using a punch. A highly developed venous plexus was observed immediately below the laminae in the epidural space. Massive epidural bleeding persisted, requiring continuous control with Floseal and bipolar coagulation.  
4. Partial resection of the C5 and C6 spinous processes was performed. Retraction of the C5 and C6 to the left was challenging due to persistent epidural bleeding. A left C6-7 foraminotomy was initiated first. Drilling laterally at the C6 V point confirmed the medial border of the facet. Further exposure of the C6 laminae was performed to open the roof of the neural foramen, confirming the exit of the C7 root. Epidural bleeding continued, complicating the procedure. Some perineural tissue around the root was removed.  
5. The C5 and C6 laminae were retracted leftward, and open door laminoplasty was performed using the CAPAX OD Plate & Screw system for fixation. No IOM changes occurred during the procedure. A hemovac suction device was placed, and the wound was closed layer by layer. The patient was awakened and transferred to the recovery room.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 8:49 AM"

Intraoperative Findings: No surgical findings > LP at C3-4-5-6, C2 undercutting, right open L4-5 posterior decompression, right app&bilateral decompression -> disc extrusion or protrusion not observed on right side. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) change (-)  
Surgical Technique & Procedure:  
1. Under general anesthesia, patient positioned prone with neck flexion, Mayfield head fixation, antiseptics, aseptic draping performed. IOM setup completed.  
2. Level confirmed with C-arm, midline skin incision made from C2 spinous process to C7 spinous process. Nuchal ligament avascular plane followed to expose spinous process, subperiosteal dissection performed to expose bilateral laminae and lateral masses near the area. Level reconfirmed with C-arm.  
3. C2: Inferior margin of some laminae removed using punch. C3 to V point: Hinge created medially on left side (4mm cutting burr), gutter formed on right side. Open door laminoplasty performed on C3-6 using cervical osteosynthetic device (OD) plate and screws. Diffuse bleeding observed. Spinolaminar flap elevated to confirm dura bulging posteriorly and decompression.  
4. Hemostasis achieved with Floseal, hemovac 1ea inserted. Wound closed layer by layer. Re-draped and proceeded to L4-5 posterior decompression.  
   1. Level confirmed with C-arm, midline skin incision made from end of L4 spinous process to end of L5 spinous process. Subperiosteal dissection performed on right side only. L4-5 pedicle-to-pedicle confirmed with C-arm. Partial hemilaminectomy performed on right side using burr, including inferior lamina and interlaminar space. Base of spinous process further modified with diamond burr for better visualization. Thickened ligamentum flavum identified and removed with punch and pituitary forceps to achieve central decompression. Dura lateral margin examined to confirm left L5 root exit. Lateral recess and L5 pedicle area decompressed by removing surrounding bony structures. Disc space confirmed after dura retraction, no disc extrusion or protrusion observed.  
   2. Contralateral ligamentum flavum removed. Less central stenosis on contralateral side, so partial ligamentum flavum retained. Base of spinous process further modified with punch.  
   3. Saline irrigation performed, hemostasis achieved with Floseal. JP 1ea inserted, wound closed layer by layer. Patient awakened and transferred to recovery room.

Intraoperative Findings:  
> C4-5-6 Corpectomy and Mesh Insertion, C3 & C7 VB Plate Insertion (Right Side Anterior Approach)  
Infection-related fibrotic tissue was the primary finding. Six swab cultures for pus and two tissue cultures for prevertebral soft tissue were sent.  
Mesh: Synmesh (12-88mm)  
Cervical Plate: 3-Level 54mm  
Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. General anesthesia was administered with the patient in a supine position and head in neutral alignment. An aseptic draping was performed on the right side for the anterior approach (intraoperative monitoring was not performed due to the surgery occurring after a standard procedure time).  
2. An oblique incision was made on the right side to cover the C3-7 level. The skin and subcutaneous layer were incised, followed by dissection to identify the platysma. The omohyoid muscle was dissected, and the carotid sheath was located on the lateral side. Fibrotic tissue adherent to the right side longus colli muscle was identified (likely from a prior tracheostomy surgery). Tissue cultures were sent for the fibrotic tissue, which was then removed. The longus colli muscles were observed to be infected, with partial remnants of C4 and C6 VBs and complete absence of C5 VBs confirmed via C-arm imaging. Pus-like lesions were replaced with fibrotic tissue, and swab cultures were sent for pus. Fibrotic tissue was maximally removed, and residual pus-like lesions were cleared during irrigation.  
3. C4 and C6 corpectomy was performed, with the intervertebral discs at C3-4 and C6-7 retained. The PLL, dura, and epidural phlegma at the C4-5 level were noted, with severe adhesion obscuring layer boundaries. Epidural phlegma was maximally removed at the C5 level to expose the dura (no dura injury was observed intraoperatively).  
4. Synmesh (12-88mm) was placed at the C4-5-6 anterior portion and confirmed with C-arm imaging. To address instability, the anterior portions of C3 and C7 VBs were fixed with a 3-level 54mm plate and screws, confirmed via C-arm imaging.  
5. Irrigation and hemostasis were performed, followed by H-vac insertion and layer-by-layer suturing from the muscle fascia layer. The patient was extubated and transferred to the SICU.  
Writer: [NAME]/[NAME]  
Writing Time: [DATE] 1:16 PM"

**Surgical End Time:** [DATE] 2:50:00 PM  

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
> No significant intraoperative changes. Cervical laminoplasty was performed at C3 and C5–C6 levels. Right-side open-door technique (open door method) was utilized. A Capax plate (GS Medical) was applied, with screws including Capax screws (GS Medical) at 2.4 mm (5 mm length, 11 pieces) and 2.9 mm (5 mm length, 1 piece).  

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia, with head fixation using a Mayfield frame. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline, vertical skin incision was made to include the C3–C7 levels. The muscular layer was dissected and detached to expose both laminae and the spinous process.  
3. High-speed drilling was performed at C3 and C5–C6 levels to create a hinge site on the left and a gutter on the right. Using a dissector and punch, the gutter side was opened to expose the dura. A center piece plate and screws (GS Medical) were applied to secure the open-door laminoplasty.  
4. Irrigation was performed, and a single closed drain was inserted. The wound was closed in layers, and the procedure was completed.  

**Postoperative Course:**  
No significant intraoperative changes were observed. The patient was transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) following the procedure.  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Date:** [DATE] 7:55 AM"

Intraoperative Findings:  
- *C5-6 ACDF, Right approach  
- Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) change: Negative  
- Muscle was extremely thick, making retraction difficult.  

Surgical Technique and Procedure:  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned supine with neck extension. Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) was set up, and the C5-6 vertebral body (VB) level was confirmed using a C-arm. A right-sided approach incision line was marked for the procedure. Antiseptic and aseptic draping were performed as usual.  
2. A transverse incision was made along the marked line to open the skin and subcutaneous layer, revealing the platysma muscle. This was carefully dissected, followed by dissection along the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) medial border to identify the C5-6 VB and bilateral longus colli muscles. The thick muscle and deep surgical field posed significant challenges. Bipolar cautery was used for meticulous bleeding control, and paravertebral tissues were organized.  
3. Retractors were placed on the left/right and anterior/posterior sides to ensure a clear surgical field. A 15-blade annulotome was used to perform the discectomy. Disc material was removed in a piecemeal fashion using a pituitary forcep and curette. A long pin was inserted into the C5 and C6 VB midline, and a retractor was used to widen the intervertebral disc space. Additional disc material was removed to create space for the cage. The posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was identified and carefully detached using a blunt hook for removal.  
4. After meticulous bleeding control, a bone chip-filled Innotec Cage (12×14×H6) was inserted into the C5-6 intervertebral space under C-arm guidance. The expanded disc height was confirmed.  
5. Massive saline irrigation was performed to ensure no active bleeding, followed by the insertion of a JP drain. The wound was closed in layers.  
- Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM) showed no significant findings.  
- The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  

Author: [NAME]/[NAME]/[NAME]  
Documentation Date: [DATE] 11:47"

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
> No significant findings during surgery.  
> Laminectomy performed at C4-5 and C6 levels, with upper laminectomy at C6 and left-sided laminectomy at C4/5, 5/6. Foraminotomy was also conducted at Lt. C4/5 and 5/6 to decompress the C5,6 nerve roots.  
**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. The patient was placed in the prone position under general anesthesia using a Mayfield fixator to achieve neck flexion and head fixation. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A midline, vertical skin incision was made to include the C3-C6 levels. Subperiosteal dissection was performed to expose the bilateral C4,5,6 laminae and spinous processes. The levels were confirmed using a C-arm.  
3. C5 and C6 levels showed significant facet arthropathy with fusion between the segments. A laminectomy was planned, and high-speed drilling was performed for C6 upper laminectomy and C5 laminectomy. Drilling of the C4 lamina created a hinge site on the right and a gutter on the left. However, a hinge fracture occurred during reflection, necessitating laminectomy of C4 as well. Additionally, left-sided C4/5 and 5/6 foraminotomy was performed to decompress the C5,6 nerve roots.  
4. Meticulous bleeding control and irrigation were performed, followed by hemostatic agent insertion. The wound was closed layer by layer, and the surgery was concluded.  
**Postoperative:** The patient was transferred to the recovery room. No significant IOM changes were observed during surgery.

1. Patient placed in supine position on a chest pad. Head fixation achieved using a Mayfield fixator. C-arm confirmed C2 and C7, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. Midline skin incision and subperiosteal dissection performed to expose C2–C7 spinous processes and C3–C6 bilateral laminae. For left-side opening, a high-speed drill was used to create a V-point drilling of the laminae, allowing access to the left side, while a hinge was created on the right side.  
3. Carefully elevated the laminae using a capax OD plate and screws to perform laminoplasty on C3, C4, and C6. Laminectomy was performed on C5. Due to sufficient space for the spinal cord in the C6/7 interlaminar space, partial laminectomy was performed on the upper C7. Additionally, a left-sided C6/7 foraminotomy was conducted.  
4. A Hemovac drain was inserted on the left side, followed by layer-by-layer wound closure. The patient was repositioned to supine, extubated, and transferred to the recovery room.

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
> ACDF, C4-5, Right approach & Lateral mass screw insertion & posterior fixation, C4-5. Intraoperative Neurophysiological Monitoring (IONM) change (-). Traumatic findings such as contusion, hematoma were identified. Spinal cord swelling + <Instrument> C7 cage 12*14*H5 1ea, surefuse 1cc 1ea, athena plate 24mm 1ea, athena screw 14mm 4ea, poseidon screw 3.5-14mm 4ea, poseidon rod 30mm 2ea.  

**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
**<ACDF, C4-5>**  
1. Patient placed in supine position on headrest. IONM applied. C-arm confirmed C4-5 level, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. Transverse skin incision performed from the right SCM medial border to midline at C4-5 level. Platysma muscle was incised, and the subcutaneous space was dissected thoroughly. SCM muscle and omohyoid muscle were identified. Carotid pulse was palpated manually, and dissection followed the SCM medial border to separate the carotid sheath laterally and the airway medially, reaching the vertebral body. Midline was reconfirmed via symmetric appearance of the longus colli muscle. Caspar screw insertion was performed, followed by retractor placement to expose the C4-5 intervertebral disc.  
3. Contusion and hematoma were present in the right SCM muscle and longus colli muscle. C4-5 intervertebral disc showed bony spur development, with intact anterior longitudinal ligament (ALL) and annulus. No. 15 blade was used to incise the disc, and disc material was removed under microscopic view. Cortical bone of C4 and C5 was drilled. A C7 cage H5 1ea was inserted, and the athena plate 24mm was fixed with 14mm screws. C-arm confirmed screw and plate position with no alignment changes. J-P 1ea was inserted, followed by layer-by-layer wound closure.  

**<Posterior Fixation, C4-5>**  
1. Patient repositioned to prone position. Mayfield fixator applied for fixation. C-arm rechecked for level, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. Midline skin incision performed, followed by subperiosteal dissection to expose bilateral C4-5 lamina and lateral masses. Poseidon screws 3.5-14mm were inserted for C4-5 lateral mass fixation. A 30mm rod was cut to 27mm length for rod fixation, followed by finalization.  
3. Hemovac 1ea was inserted, and wound closure was performed layer by layer. Patient repositioned to supine, extubated, and transferred to SICU.  

**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Time:** [DATE] 7:05 PM"

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
> Laminectomy at C4-5 with Intraoperative Neurophysiological Monitoring (IONM) showing no changes (-).  
**Procedure and Technique:**  
1. Patient placed in supine position on a chest pad with head fixation using a Mayfield fixator. Intraoperative Neurophysiological Monitoring (IONM) was applied. Aseptic draping was performed.  
2. The midline skin incision was made at the level of C4-5, centered between C4 and C5, with dissection following the nuchal ligament. A calcification was observed in the posterior region of C4-5, and the spinous process, bilateral lamina, and facet joints were exposed.  
3. Due to degenerative changes in the facet joints, which complicated the placement of a stable plate, and the narrow interlaminar space, laminoplasty was deemed unsuitable. The procedure was considered unstable, so a laminectomy at C4-5 was performed. Using a rongeur, the spinous process of C4-5 was removed. The bilateral laminae were then removed with a high-speed drill, and residual bone was carefully excised with a Kerrison rongeur. The central canal space was confirmed to be adequate above at C3/4 and below at C5/6.  
4. Bleeding was controlled meticulously using bipolar coagulation and Floseal. A Hemovac drain was placed on the right side. The wound was closed layer by layer. The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]  
**Completion Time:** [DATE] 6:58 PM"

Surgical Record: Neurosurgery ([DATE])  
Procedure: Laminoplasty, Cervical Spine (C4-5-6, Right Open)  
Preoperative Diagnosis: Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy  
Postoperative Diagnosis: Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy  
Anesthesia Type: General  
Surgical Date: [DATE]  
Primary Surgeon: [NAME]  
Assistant: [NAME]  
Start Time: [DATE] at 9:59 AM  
End Time: [DATE] at 11:49 AM  
Intraoperative Notes:  
- No significant intraoperative monitoring changes noted.  
- Laminoplasty performed on C4, Right Open; Total Laminectomy on C5; Upper Laminectomy on C6.  
- Intraoperative Monitoring (IOM): No changes.  
- CAPAX OD PLATE (10mm x 1 piece) and CAPAX SCREW (2.4mm x 5mm x 4 pieces) used.  
Surgical Technique & Procedure:  
1. Patient placed in prone position with head fixation using a Mayfield frame. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) was installed, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. Midline, vertical skin incision was performed from C3 to C6. Muscle dissection and detachment were conducted to expose bilateral laminae and spinous processes.  
3. High-speed drill was used to create a hinge site on the left side and a gutter on the right side of C4-C5. The gutter side (right) was opened using a dissector and punch to expose the dura. Open-door laminoplasty was performed using a C4 center piece plate and screws (Medtronic).  
4. For C5 laminoplasty, a plate was initially planned, but due to size mismatch, total laminectomy was performed on the left side of C5.

Intraoperative Notes:

- Implants: Inovis C7 cage (cervical interbody fusion device) 12*14*H6 - 1ea, Inovis Athena plate (cervical fusion device) 24mm - 1ea, Inovis Athena screw (cervical fixation device) 4.0*14mm - 4ea.  

Surgical Procedure and Technique:  
1. Patient placed in supine position with neutral head alignment and slight neck extension. C-arm fluoroscope confirmed the C5-6 intervertebral space level. Intraoperative monitoring (IOM) settings were established, followed by aseptic draping.  
2. A linear incision was made obliquely to include the left-sided C5-6 level. Platysma muscle was incised, and the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle was retracted laterally. The omohyoid muscle was identified, and dissection proceeded along the avascular plane medial to the carotid sheath. The C5-6 vertebral body was exposed, with the longus colli muscles detached from the vertebral body.  
3. Casper screws were inserted bilaterally into the C5-6 vertebral body. A retractor was placed on the screws to widen the intervertebral space. The endplate was drilled, followed by annulotomy and removal of disc material. The left-sided calcified disc with severe adhesion to the posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) was carefully dissected and removed, ensuring decompression of the thecal sac and dura.  
4. A C-arm guided placement of the Inovis C7 cage (cervical interbody fusion device) 12*14*H6 was performed. The casper screws were removed, and the site was sealed with Surgicel. A plate and screws were applied to stabilize the C5-6 vertebral body, completing the ACDF procedure (C5-6 laminoplasty necessitated plate application).  
5. Hemostasis was achieved, and a JP drain was inserted. The wound was closed layer by layer starting from the platysma muscle. The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room.

All the data you receive was collected before the surgery, with the exception of the operative note, which is generated during the surgery. The full spectrum of potentially available data includes:
- Imaging Data: MR T2 Sagittal, MR T2 Axial.
- Text Data: Radiology reports for the MR/XR, the pre-operative admission note, and the operative note.
- Tabular Data: Patient demographics, past medical history, pre-operative lab results, and pre-operative symptoms.
For any given patient, you will receive a subset of this data, as specified in the task. Your analysis must be based only on the data provided for that specific task.
</CLINICAL_SCENARIO>

<PRIMARY_TASK>
Your task is to analyze the provided patient data and output a structured JSON object that predicts the 1-year post-operative JOA score.
</PRIMARY_TASK>

<INSTRUCTIONS>
Analyze all provided data comprehensively:
- Review all imaging findings, clinical data, and patient characteristics
- Identify factors that positively or negatively impact post-operative prognosis
- Synthesize information across all modalities to form an integrated assessment
- Consider which factors are most impactful for recovery
- Provide a precise integer for the post-operative JOA score (0: worst, 17: normal).
- Provide Rationale: Write a clear, specific, and detailed rationale that directly summarizes the most critical factors that led to that specific numerical prediction.
- Consider both the baseline status and expected recovery to determine the final post-operative score.
- The rationale should explain how the imaging findings, clinical data, surgical factors, and patient characteristics contribute to your predicted post-operative JOA score.
</INSTRUCTIONS>

<OUTPUT_FORMAT>
Your entire output must be a single, valid JSON object. Do not include any text, greetings, or explanations outside of the JSON structure itself.
```json
{
  "rationale": "<clear, specific, and detailed explanation>",
  "score": <integer 0-17>
}
```
</OUTPUT_FORMAT>

**Intraoperative Findings:**  
- **No surgical complications observed.**  
- **C5 Total Laminectomy & C6 Open Laminoplasty (Left Open):** Due to cord swelling at the C5–6 level, a total laminectomy was performed at C5. A laminoplasty was completed at C6 using a capax plate (10 mm, 1 piece) secured with screws (capax, 2.4×5 mm, 4 pieces).  
- **C7 Upper Laminectomy:** The upper lamina of C7 was removed using a punch. Adequate space was confirmed in the central canal, and no hinge-related bone fracture was observed.  
**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. **Positioning and Setup:** Patient placed in supine position on a chest pad. Head fixed with a Mayfield fixator. Intraoperative neuromonitoring (IONM) applied. Aseptic draping completed.  
2. **Exposure:** C-arm used to confirm C5, C6, and C7 spinous processes. After palpating C4 and C7, a midline skin incision was performed along the nuchal ligament. Spinous processes and bilateral laminae/facets of C4–7 were exposed.  
   - **C5–C6 Decompression:** Rongeur used to remove partial spinous processes at C5 and C6. High-speed drill created a hinge on the right side of C5–C6 laminae, while the left side was opened. Penfield 1 was used to reflect laminae while removing ligamentum flavum connections.  
   - **C5 Total Laminectomy:** Due to cord bulging at C5–6, a total laminectomy was performed at C5.  
   - **C6 Laminoplasty:** A capax plate (10 mm) was secured with screws to complete the laminoplasty at C6.  
3. **C7 Decompression:** Upper lamina of C7 was removed with a punch.  
4. **Closure:** Meticulous hemostasis achieved. Hemovac (1 piece) placed on the left side. Wound closed in layers.  
**Intraoperative Monitoring:** No significant changes noted. Patient extubated and transferred to recovery.  
**Author:** [NAME]/[NAME]/[NAME]  
**Date:** [DATE] [TIME]"

**Intraoperative Notes:**  
- No significant intraoperative monitoring (IOM) changes observed.  
- ACDF at C5-6 (Right Approach): IOM settings were confirmed (-). Cage: Innotec C7 intervertebral cage (12×14×H5).  
**Surgical Technique and Procedure:**  
1. Under general anesthesia, the patient was positioned supine with the head in neutral alignment and slight neck extension. The C5-6 intervertebral space level was confirmed using a C-arm. Aseptic draping was performed after IOM settings were established.  
2. A transverse incision was made to include the C5-6 level on the right side. The platysma muscle was incised, and the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle was retracted laterally. The anterior aspect of the C5-6 vertebral body was exposed, and the longus colli muscle adherent to the vertebral body was detached. The C5-6 vertebral body and intervertebral space were then identified.  
3. A single Casper screw was inserted into the midline of the C5-6 vertebral body. A retractor was placed on the Casper screws to maximize the C5-6 intervertebral space. The C5-6 endplate was drilled, followed by annulotomy of the anterior disc space. The disc material was removed, and the uncinate processes were identified.  
4. Under C-arm guidance, an Innotec C7 intervertebral cage was inserted into the C5-6 intervertebral space. The Casper screws were removed, and the removal site was sealed with Surgicel.  
5. Hemostasis was achieved on the operating table, and a JP drain (1 unit) was inserted. The wound was closed in layers starting from the platysma muscle. The patient was extubated and transferred to the recovery room without significant intraoperative complications.
